{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} [[Malay titles|Tan Sri]] '''Abdul Samad bin Ismail''' (18 April 1924{{spaced ndash}}4 September 2008), who often went by the moniker '''Pak Samad''', was a Malaysian journalist, writer and editor.
== Early life == Samad was born on 18 April 1924, in Singapore to [[Javanese people|Javanese immigrant]] parents,<ref name="Magsaysay"/> where he also attended [[Victoria School]].<ref name=star>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Pak Samad dies at 84 |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/9/5/nation/22246821&sec=nation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905095718/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2008%2F9%2F5%2Fnation%2F22246821&sec=nation |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 September 2008 |work=[[The Star (Malaysia)]] |publisher= |date=5 September 2008 |accessdate=13 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He completed a [[Senior Cambridge]] [[General Certificate of Education|certificate]] as a cub reporter at the daily newspaper, ''[[Utusan Melayu]]'', where he began his career in journalism in 1940.<ref name=star/>
Samad's family is "very conscious" of their Javanese heritage, and Samad himself spoke English with thick Javanese accent.<ref>{{cite book |first= Kheng Cheah |last=Boon |title=A. Samad Ismail: Journalism & Politics |publisher=Utusan Pub. & Distributors |year=2000 |url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=ih5lAAAAMAAJ }} </ref>
== Career == During the [[Japanese occupation of Malaya]] during [[World War II]], Samad worked for the Japanese-supported newspaper, ''[[Berita Malai]]''.<ref name=star/> He became editor of ''Berita Malai'' when he was just 21 years old.<ref name=star/> The British, who controlled Malaysia during the [[colonial era]], returned following the Japanese defeat and briefly imprisoned Samad.<ref name=star/> He was released after a short time and returned to work at the ''[[Utusan Melayu]]''.<ref name=star/>
Samad wrote extensively in support of Malaysian independence from the United Kingdom. He often met with the Malay supporters of independence, as well as the separatists who were against Dutch rule in nearby [[Indonesia]].<ref name=star/> For his actions, Samad was arrested by the British authorities again in 1951.<ref name=star/> He was released from prison in 1953 and again returned to work at ''Utusan Melayu''.
Samad founded the [[People's Action Party]] (PAP) with [[Lee Kuan Yew]], the future [[Prime Minister of Singapore]].<ref name=star/> However, disagreements between Samad and both Lee and the ''Utusan Melayu'' resulted in his move to the city of [[Kuala Lumpur]]. While in Kuala Lumpur, Samad became the head of the ''[[Berita Harian]]'' newspaper and the managing editor of the [[New Straits Times Press]] (NSTP) group.<ref name=star/>
Samad promoted several social causes within his writing in post-independence Malaysia. He drew attention to social inequalities within Malaysian society, called for the national [[standardisation]] of the [[Malay language]] and reported on the sometimes complex relationship between race and [[Malaysian politics]].<ref name=star/>
For his writings on social issues, which were popular with the public, Samad was arrested in 1976 under the [[Internal Security Act (Malaysia)|Internal Security Act]].<ref name=star/> He was finally released from prison five years later in 1981.<ref name=star/><ref name="Justin 1">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=vhBMmG9yXgYC&pg=PA14 |pages=14– |title=Historical Dictionary of Singapore |first=Justin |last=Corfield |publisher=Scarecrow Press |year=2010 |isbn=9780810873872 }}</ref>
Samad rejoined the New Straits Times Press group following his release from prison as an editorial adviser. He retired from full-time journalism in 1988.<ref name=star/>
== Awards == He was honoured for his contribution in 1992 by the [[King of Malaysia]], who at the time was [[Sultan Azlan Shah of Perak]].<ref name=star/> Samad also separately received the [[Pejuang Sastera]] (Literature Champion) for literature and journalism.<ref name=star/>
He was also awarded the [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] for [[List of Magsaysay awardees|Journalism, Literature and Creative Communications Arts]] in 1994 for his efforts in support of Malaysian independence, democratic [[nation building]] and Malay cultural revival in Malaysia.<ref name="Magsaysay">[http://www.rmaf.org.ph/Awardees/Biography/BiographySamadIsmailAbd.htm 1994 Ramon Magsaysay Awardee for Journalism, Literature, and the Creative Communication Arts – Abdul Samad Ismail]</ref> <ref name=star/>
== Death == Samad died quietly on the evening 4 September 2008, at [[Pantai Medical Centre]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]]. He succumbed from a severe lung infection and kidney failure at the age of 84.<ref name=star/> Prior to this, he had been hospitalised in the intensive care unit since 24 August 2008, due to breathing difficulties.<ref name=star/>
[[Lee Kuan Yew]] sent his condolences to Samad's son, describing him as able and shrewd though with an innate ability to accept changed realities. In the condolence letter, Lee said that they were friends even though they had parted company politically. When Samad wanted to visit his family in Singapore, Lee had recommended that the entry ban on Samad be lifted.<ref>http://www.channelnewsasia.com/palmnews/singaporelocalnews/view/374318/1/.html{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Samad was survived by his children (whom he had with his first wife, Hamidah Hassan), as well as his grandchildren & great grandchildren. He had ten children during his life, eight of whom are still living.<ref name=star/> He had two sons, Hamed and Kamal, and daughters Maria, Norlin, Nuraina, Norazah, Nurazlin and Nurazrina. Maria and Nuraina (http://nursamad.blogspot.com) are former journalists and are active [[bloggers]].
<ref name=star/> Samad's first wife, Hamidah Hassan, had died in 1990.<ref name=star/>
He was buried at the [[Bukit Kiara Muslim Cemetery|Muslim cemetery]] in [[Bukit Kiara]], where Hamidah was also buried.<ref name=star/>
==Honour== ===Honour of Malaysia=== * {{flagu|Malaysia}} : Commander of the [[Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia#Commander|Order of Loyalty to the Crown of Malaysia]] (P.S.M.) (1992)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.istiadat.gov.my/index.php/component/semakanlantikanskp/|title=Semakan Penerima Darjah Kebesaran, Bintang dan Pingat}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726005410/http://www.dummipedia.org/Chronology%3AAbdul_Samad_Ismail Chronology: Abdul Samad Ismail]

'''Advanced glycation end products''' ('''AGEs''') are proteins or lipids that become [[Glycation|glycated]] as a result of exposure to sugars.<ref>{{cite web|title=American Heart Association|url=http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/114/6/597.full|accessdate=5 May 2016}}</ref> They can be a factor in aging and in the development or worsening of many [[degenerative diseases]], such as [[diabetes]], [[atherosclerosis]], [[chronic kidney disease]], and [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Vistoli|first=G|author2=De Maddis, D|author3= Cipak, A|author4= Zarkovic, N|author5= Carini, M|author6= Aldini, G|title=Advanced glycoxidation and lipoxidation end products (AGEs and ALEs): an overview of their mechanisms of formation.|journal=Free Radic Res.|date=Aug 2013|volume=47|pages=Suppl 1:3–27.|pmid=23767955|doi=10.3109/10715762.2013.815348}} </ref>
==Dietary sources== Animal-derived foods that are high in fat and protein are generally AGE-rich and are prone to further AGE formation during cooking.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Uribarri et al|first1=Jaime|date=|year=2010|title=Advanced Glycation End Products in Foods and a Practical Guide to Their Reduction in the Diet|url=|journal=Journal of the American Dietetic Association|volume=110|issue=6|pages=911–916|doi=10.1016/j.jada.2010.03.018|pmc=3704564|via=}}</ref>
==Effects== AGEs affect nearly every type of cell and molecule in the body and are thought to be one factor in aging and some age-related chronic diseases.<ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Glenn | first1 = J.| last2 = Stitt | first2 = A.| title = The role of advanced glycation end products in retinal ageing and disease| journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta| volume = 1790| issue = 10| pages = 1109–1116| year = 2009| pmid = 19409449| doi = 10.1016/j.bbagen.2009.04.016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1007/BF03325227| pmid = 19448391| year = 2009| last1 = Semba | first1 = R. D.| last2 = Ferrucci| last3 = Sun| last4 = Beck| last5 = Dalal| last6 = Varadhan| last7 = Walston| last8 = Guralnik| last9 = Fried| title = Advanced glycation end products and their circulating receptors predict cardiovascular disease mortality in older community-dwelling women| volume = 21| issue = 2| pages = 182–190| journal = Aging clinical and experimental research | first2 = L. | first3 = K. | first4 = J. | first5 = M. | first6 = R. | first7 = J. | first8 = J. M. | first9 = L. P.| pmc = 2684987}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Semba | first1 = R.| last2 = Najjar | first2 = S.| last3 = Sun | first3 = K.| last4 = Lakatta | first4 = E.| last5 = Ferrucci | first5 = L.| title = Serum carboxymethyl-lysine, an advanced glycation end product, is associated with increased aortic pulse wave velocity in adults| journal = American Journal of Hypertension| volume = 22| issue = 1| pages = 74–79| year = 2009| pmid = 19023277| doi = 10.1038/ajh.2008.320| pmc = 2637811}}</ref> They are also believed to play a causative role in the vascular complications of [[diabetes mellitus]].<ref>{{Cite journal| pmid = 18331228| year = 2007| last1 = Yan | first1 = S. F.| last2 = D'Agati| last3 = Schmidt| last4 = Ramasamy| title = Receptor for Advanced Glycation Endproducts (RAGE): a formidable force in the pathogenesis of the cardiovascular complications of diabetes & aging| volume = 7| issue = 8| pages = 699–710| journal = Current Molecular Medicine| doi = 10.2174/156652407783220732 | first2 = V. | first3 = A. M. | first4 = R.}}</ref>
Under certain pathologic conditions, such as [[oxidative stress]] due to [[hyperglycemia]] in patients with [[diabetes]],<ref name=BROWNLEE2005>{{cite journal|last=Brownlee|first=M|title=The pathobiology of diabetic complications: a unifying mechanism.|journal=Diabetes|date=June 2005|volume=54|issue=6|pages=1615–25|pmid=15919781|doi=10.2337/diabetes.54.6.1615}}</ref> and [[hyperlipidemia]],{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} AGE formation can be increased beyond normal levels. AGEs are now known to play a role as proinflammatory mediators in [[gestational diabetes]] as well.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pertyńska-Marczewska|first=M|author2=Głowacka, E|author3= Sobczak, M|author4= Cypryk, K|author5= Wilczyński, J|title=Glycation endproducts, soluble receptor for advanced glycation endproducts and cytokines in diabetic and non-diabetic pregnancies.|journal=American journal of reproductive immunology (New York, N.Y. : 1989)|date=February 2009|volume=61|issue=2|pages=175–82|pmid=19143681|doi=10.1111/j.1600-0897.2008.00679.x}}</ref>
The animal and human evidence is that significant amounts of dietary advanced glycation end-products (dAGEs) are absorbed, and that dAGEs contribute to the body's burden of AGE, and are associated with diseases such as atherosclerosis and kidney disease.<ref name=foods>{{cite journal|last=Uribarri|first=J|author2=Woodruff, S|author3=Goodman, S|author4=Cai, W|author5=Chen, X|author6=Pyzik, R|author7=Yong, A|author8=Striker, GE|author9= Vlassara, H|title=Advanced glycation end products in foods and a practical guide to their reduction in the diet|journal=Journal of the American Dietetic Association|date=June 2010|volume=110|issue=6|pages=911–16.e12|pmid=20497781|doi=10.1016/j.jada.2010.03.018|pmc=3704564}}</ref>
In the context of cardiovascular disease, AGEs can induce crosslinking of collagen which can cause vascular stiffening and entrapment of low-density lipoprotein particles (LDL) in the artery walls. AGEs can also cause glycation of LDL which can promote its oxidation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Advanced glycation end products and diabetic cardiovascular disease|url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=Advanced+Glycation+End+Products+and+Diabetic+Cardiovascular+Disease+Anand+Prasad%252C+MD%252C*+Peter+Bekker%252C+MD%252C%25E2%2580%25A0+and+Sotirios+Tsimikas%252C+MD%25E2%2580%25A0|journal = Cardiology in Review|date = 2012-08-01|issn = 1538-4683|pmid = 22314141|pages = 177–183|volume = 20|issue = 4|doi = 10.1097/CRD.0b013e318244e57c|first = Anand|last = Prasad|first2 = Peter|last2 = Bekker|first3 = Sotirios|last3 = Tsimikas}}</ref> Oxidized LDL is one of the major factors in the development of atherosclerosis.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Diabetes alters activation and repression of pro- and anti-inflammatory signaling pathways in the vasculature|journal = Frontiers in Endocrinology|date = 2013-01-01|issn = 1664-2392|pmc = 3672854|pmid = 23761786|pages = 68|volume = 4|doi = 10.3389/fendo.2013.00068|first = Elyse|last = Di Marco|first2 = Stephen P.|last2 = Gray|first3 = Karin|last3 = Jandeleit-Dahm}}</ref> Finally, AGEs can bind to [[RAGE (receptor)|RAGE (receptor for advanced glycation end products)]] and cause oxidative stress as well as activation of inflammatory pathways in vascular endothelial cells.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
===In other diseases=== The formation and accumulation of advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs) has been implicated in the progression of age-related diseases.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tan|first=KC|author2=Chow, WS|author3=Lam, JC|author4=Lam, B|author5=Bucala, R|author6=Betteridge, J|author7= Ip, MS|title=Advanced glycation endproducts in nondiabetic patients with obstructive sleep apnea.|journal=Sleep|date=March 2006|volume=29|issue=3|pages=329–33|pmid=16553018}}</ref> AGEs have been implicated in Alzheimer's Disease,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Srikanth|first=V|author2=Maczurek, A|author3=Phan, T|author4=Steele, M|author5=Westcott, B|author6=Juskiw, D|author7= Münch, G|title=Advanced glycation endproducts and their receptor RAGE in Alzheimer's disease.|journal=Neurobiology of Aging|date=May 2011|volume=32|issue=5|pages=763–77|pmid=19464758|doi=10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2009.04.016}}</ref> cardiovascular disease,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Simm|first=A|author2=Wagner, J|author3=Gursinsky, T|author4=Nass, N|author5=Friedrich, I|author6=Schinzel, R|author7=Czeslik, E|author8=Silber, RE|author9= Scheubel, RJ|title=Advanced glycation endproducts: a biomarker for age as an outcome predictor after cardiac surgery?|journal=Experimental Gerontology|date=July 2007|volume=42|issue=7|pages=668–75|pmid=17482402|doi=10.1016/j.exger.2007.03.006}}</ref> and stroke.<ref>Zimmerman GA, Meistrell M 3rd, Bloom O, Cockroft KM, Bianchi M, Risucci D, Broome J, Farmer P, Cerami A, Vlassara H, et al. Neurotoxicity of advanced glycation endproducts during focal stroke and neuroprotective effects of aminoguanidine. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America 1995 Apr 25;92(9):3744-8.</ref> The mechanism by which AGEs induce damage is through a process called [[cross-link]]ing that causes intracellular damage and apoptosis.<ref>Shaikh S, Nicholson LF. Advanced glycation end products induce in vitro cross-linking of alpha-synuclein and accelerate the process of intracellular inclusion body formation. J Neurosci Res. 2008 Jul;86(9):2071-82.</ref> They form photosensitizers in the crystalline lens,<ref>Fuentealba D, Friguet B, Silva E. Advanced glycation endproducts induce photocrosslinking and oxidation of bovine lens proteins through type-I mechanism. Photochem Photobiol. 2009 Jan-Feb;85(1):185-94.</ref> which has implications for cataract development.<ref>Gul A, Rahman MA, Hasnain SN. Role of fructose concentration on cataractogenesis in senile diabetic and non-diabetic patients. Graefes Arch Clin Exp Ophthalmol. 2009 Jun;247(6):809-14.</ref> Reduced muscle function is also associated with AGEs.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Haus|first=JM|author2=Carrithers, JA|author3= Trappe, SW|author4= Trappe, TA|title=Collagen, cross-linking, and advanced glycation end products in aging human skeletal muscle.|journal=Journal of Applied Physiology|date=December 2007|volume=103|issue=6|pages=2068–76|pmid=17901242|doi=10.1152/japplphysiol.00670.2007}}</ref> <!-- not disease specific Because AGEs are related to elevated blood sugar levels, a low calorie diet may reduce AGE body load.<ref>Gugliucci A, Kotani K, Taing J, Matsuoka Y, Sano Y, Yoshimura M, Egawa K, Horikawa C, Kitagawa Y, Kiso Y, Kimura S, Sakane N. Short-Term Low Calorie Diet Intervention Reduces Serum Advanced Glycation End Products in Healthy Overweight or Obese Adults. Ann Nutr Metab. 2009 May 6;54(3):197-201.</ref> -->
===Pathology=== AGEs have a range of [[Pathology|pathological effects]], such as:<ref name=GUGLIUCCI1996/><ref name=yan/> * Increased [[vascular permeability]]. * Increased [[arterial stiffness]] * Inhibition of [[Vasodilation|vascular dilation]] by interfering with [[nitric oxide]]. * [[Low-density lipoprotein#Importance of antioxidants|Oxidizing LDL]]. * Binding cells—including [[macrophage]], [[endothelial cell|endothelial]], and [[mesangial cell|mesangial]]—to induce the secretion of a variety of [[cytokine]]s. * Enhanced [[oxidative stress]].
==Reactivity== Proteins are usually glycated through their [[lysine]] [[Residue (chemistry)|residue]]s.<ref name="pmid21725160">{{cite journal | vauthors=Ansari NA, Moinuddin, Ali R | title=Glycated lysine residues: a marker for non-enzymatic protein glycation in age-related diseases | journal=Disease Markers | volume=30 | issue=6 | year=2011 | pages=317–324 | url = http://www.hindawi.com/journals/dm/2011/718694/abs/ | doi= 10.1155/2011/718694| pmc= 3825483 | id= | pmid=21725160}}</ref> In humans, [[histone]]s in the [[cell nucleus]] are richest in lysine, and therefore form the glycated protein [[N(6)-Carboxymethyllysine]] (CML).<ref name="pmid21725160" />
A [[receptor (biochemistry)]] nicknamed RAGE, from [[RAGE (receptor)|'''r'''eceptor for '''a'''dvanced '''g'''lycation '''e'''nd products]], is found on many cells, including [[endothelium|endothelial cells]], [[smooth muscle cells|smooth muscle]], cells of the [[immune system]] {{which|date=August 2013}} from tissue such as lung, liver, and kidney.{{clarify|date=November 2013}}{{which|date=August 2013}} This receptor, when binding AGEs, contributes to age- and diabetes-related chronic [[inflammation|inflammatory]] diseases such as [[atherosclerosis]], [[asthma]], [[arthritis]], [[myocardial infarction]], [[nephropathy]], [[retinopathy]], [[periodontitis]] and [[neuropathy]].<ref name=MechanismOf>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wells-Knecht KJ, Zyzak DV, Litchfield JE, Thorpe SR, Baynes JW | title=Mechanism of autoxidative glycosylation: identification of glyoxal and arabinose as intermediates in the autoxidative modification of proteins by glucose | journal = [[Biochemistry (journal)|Biochemistry]] | volume=34 | issue=11 | year=1995 | pages=3702–9 | pmid=7893666 | doi=10.1021/bi00011a027 }}</ref> The [[pathogenesis]] of this process hypothesized to activation of the [[Transcription factor|nuclear factor]] kappa B ([[NF-κB]]) following AGE binding. NF-κB controls several [[genes]] which are involved in [[inflammation]]. {{Citation needed|date=August 2013}}
==Clearance== In [[Clearance (medicine)|clearance]], or the rate at which a substance is removed or cleared from the body, it has been found that the cellular [[proteolysis]] of AGEs—the breakdown of proteins—produces AGE [[peptides]] and "AGE free [[adducts]]" (AGE adducts bound to single [[amino acids]]). These latter, after being released into the [[Blood plasma|plasma]], can be excreted in the [[urine]].<ref name=gugliucci>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gugliucci A, Mehlhaff K, Kinugasa E |title=Paraoxonase-1 concentrations in end-stage renal disease patients increase after hemodialysis: correlation with low molecular AGE adduct clearance |journal=Clin. Chim. Acta |volume=377 |issue=1–2 |pages=213–20 |year=2007 |pmid=17118352 |doi=10.1016/j.cca.2006.09.028|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
[[File:KidneyStructures PioM.svg|thumb|250px|left| <center> 1. [[Renal pyramid]] • 2. [[Interlobular artery]] • 3. [[Renal artery]] • 4. [[Renal vein]] 5. [[Renal hilum]] • 6. [[Renal pelvis]] • 7. [[Ureter]] • 8. [[Minor calyx]] • 9. [[Renal capsule]] • 10. [[Inferior renal capsule]] • 11. [[Superior renal capsule]] • 12. [[Interlobular vein]] • 13. [[Nephron]] • 14. [[Minor calyx]] • 15. [[Major calyx]] • 16. [[Renal papilla]] • 17. [[Renal column]] </center>]] Nevertheless, the resistance of [[extracellular matrix]] proteins to proteolysis renders their advanced glycation end products less conducive to being eliminated.<ref name=gugliucci/> While the AGE free adducts are released directly into the urine, AGE peptides are [[Endocytosis|endocytosed]] by the [[Epithelium|epithelial cells]] of the [[proximal tubule]] and then degraded by the [[lysosome|endolysosomal system]] to produce AGE amino acids. It is thought that these acids are then returned to the kidney's inside space, or [[Lumen (anatomy)|lumen]], for [[excretion]]. <ref name=GUGLIUCCI1996>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gugliucci A, Bendayan M |title=Renal fate of circulating advanced glycated end products (AGE): evidence for reabsorption and catabolism of AGE peptides by renal proximal tubular cells |journal=Diabetologia |volume=39 |issue=2 |pages=149–60 |year=1996 |pmid=8635666 | url=http://www.nature.com/ki/journal/v53/n2/full/4490049a.html |doi=10.1007/BF00403957}}</ref> AGE free adducts are the major form through which AGEs are excreted in urine, with AGE-peptides occurring to a lesser extent<ref name=GUGLIUCCI1996/> but accumulating in the plasma of patients with chronic kidney failure.<ref name=gugliucci/>
Larger, extracellularly derived AGE proteins cannot pass through the basement membrane of the [[renal corpuscle]] and must first be degraded into AGE peptides and AGE free adducts. Peripheral [[macrophage]]<ref name=GUGLIUCCI1996/> as well as liver [[Endothelium|sinusoidal endothelial cells]] and [[Kupffer cell]]s <ref name="Smedsrød">{{cite journal |vauthors=Smedsrød B, Melkko J, Araki N, Sano H, Horiuchi S |title=Advanced glycation end products are eliminated by scavenger-receptor-mediated endocytosis in hepatic sinusoidal Kupffer and endothelial cells |journal=Biochem. J. |volume=322 |issue=Pt 2 |pages=567–73 |year=1997 |pmid=9065778 |pmc=1218227 |url=http://www.biochemj.org/bj/322/0567/bj3220567.htm}}</ref> have been implicated in this process, although the real-life involvement of the liver has been disputed. <ref name=Svistounov>{{cite journal |vauthors=Svistounov D, Smedsrød B |title=Hepatic clearance of advanced glycation end products (AGEs)—myth or truth? |journal=J. Hepatol. |volume=41 |issue=6 |pages=1038–40 |year=2004 |pmid=15582139 |doi=10.1016/j.jhep.2004.10.004}}</ref>
[[File:Endotelijalna ćelija.jpg|thumb|right|Endothelial cell]] Large AGE proteins unable to enter the [[Bowman's capsule]] are capable of binding to receptors on [[Endothelium|endothelial]] and [[Mesangial cell|mesangial]] cells and to the mesangial matrix.<ref name=GUGLIUCCI1996/> Activation of RAGE induces production of a variety of [[cytokines]], including [[Tumor necrosis factors|TNFβ]], which mediates an inhibition of [[metalloproteinase]] and increases production of mesangial matrix, leading to [[glomerulosclerosis]]<ref name=yan>{{cite journal|vauthors=Yan HD, Li XZ, Xie JM, Li M |title=Effects of advanced glycation end products on renal fibrosis and oxidative stress in cultured NRK-49F cells |journal=Chin. Med. J. |volume=120 |issue=9 |pages=787–93 |year=2007 |pmid=17531120 |url=http://www.cmj.org/Periodical/paperlist.asp?id=LW2007429414606901754&linkintype=pubmed |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810100221/http://www.cmj.org/Periodical/paperlist.asp?id=LW2007429414606901754&linkintype=pubmed |archivedate=2009-08-10 }}</ref> and decreasing kidney function in patients with unusually high AGE levels.
Although the only form suitable for urinary excretion, the breakdown products of AGE—that is, peptides and free adducts—are more aggressive than the AGE proteins from which they are derived, and they can perpetuate related pathology in diabetic patients, even after [[hyperglycemia]] has been brought under control.<ref name=GUGLIUCCI1996/>
Some AGEs have an innate catalytic oxidative capacity, while activation of [[NAD(P)H oxidase]] through activation of RAGE and damage to mitochondrial proteins leading to mitochondrial dysfunction can also induce oxidative stress. A 2007 {{em|in vitro}} study found that AGEs could significantly increase expression of TGF-β1, CTGF, Fn mRNA in NRK-49F cells through enhancement of oxidative stress, and suggested that inhibition of oxidative stress might underlie the effect of ginkgo biloba extract in diabetic nephropathy. The authors suggested that antioxidant therapy might help prevent the accumulation of AGEs and induced damage.<ref name=yan/> In the end, effective clearance is necessary, and those suffering AGE increases because of kidney dysfunction might require a kidney transplant.<ref name=GUGLIUCCI1996/>
In diabetics who have an increased production of an AGE, kidney damage reduces the subsequent urinary removal of AGEs, forming a positive feedback loop that increases the rate of damage. In a 1997 study, diabetic and healthy subjects were given a single meal of egg white (56 g protein), cooked with or without 100 g of fructose; there was a greater than 200-fold increase in AGE immunoreactivity from the meal with fructose.<ref name=KOSCHINSKY1997>{{cite journal|last=Koschinsky|first=T|author2=He, CJ|author3=Mitsuhashi, T|author4=Bucala, R|author5=Liu, C|author6=Buenting, C|author7=Heitmann, K|author8= Vlassara, H|title=Orally absorbed reactive glycation products (glycotoxins): an environmental risk factor in diabetic nephropathy.|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=Jun 10, 1997|volume=94|issue=12|pages=6474–9|pmid=9177242|pmc=21074|doi=10.1073/pnas.94.12.6474}}</ref>
==Potential therapy== [[File:Resveratrol.svg|thumb|Diagram of a [[resveratrol]] molecule]] AGEs are the subject of ongoing research. There are three therapeutic approaches: preventing the formation of AGEs, breaking crosslinks after they are formed and preventing their negative effects.
Compounds that have been found to inhibit AGE formation in the laboratory include [[Vitamin C]], [[benfotiamine]], [[pyridoxamine]], [[alpha-lipoic acid]],<ref>{{cite journal|last=Abdul|first=HM|author2=Butterfield, DA|title=Involvement of PI3K/PKG/ERK1/2 signaling pathways in cortical neurons to trigger protection by cotreatment of acetyl-L-carnitine and alpha-lipoic acid against HNE-mediated oxidative stress and neurotoxicity: implications for Alzheimer's disease.|journal=Free Radical Biology & Medicine|date=Feb 1, 2007|volume=42|issue=3|pages=371–84|pmid=17210450|doi=10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2006.11.006|pmc=1808543}}</ref> [[taurine]],<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nandhini AT, Thirunavukkarasu V, Anuradha CV |title=Taurine prevents collagen abnormalities in high fructose-fed rats |journal=Indian J. Med. Res. |volume=122 |issue=2 |pages=171–7 |date=August 2005 |pmid=16177476 |url=http://www.icmr.nic.in/ijmr/2005/august/0911.pdf}}</ref> [[pimagedine]],<ref>A. Gugliucci, "[http://209.209.34.25/webdocs/Glycation%20Page/Glycation%20Page.htm Sour Side of Sugar, A Glycation Web Page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070701161048/http://209.209.34.25/webdocs/Glycation%20Page/Glycation%20Page.htm |date=July 1, 2007 }}</ref> [[aspirin]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mendeley.com/research/aspirin-inhibits-formation-pentosidine-crosslinking-advanced-glycation-end-product-collagen/ |title=Aspirin inhibits the formation of... preview & related info |doi=10.1016/j.diabres.2006.12.024 |publisher=Mendeley |accessdate=2013-11-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bucala R, Cerami A |title=Advanced glycosylation: chemistry, biology, and implications for diabetes and aging |journal=Adv. Pharmacol. |volume=23 |issue= |pages=1–34 |year=1992 |pmid=1540533 |doi=10.1016/S1054-3589(08)60961-8 |series=Advances in Pharmacology |isbn=9780120329236 }}</ref> [[carnosine]],<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.2174/0929867054864796 |vauthors=Guiotto A, Calderan A, Ruzza P, Borin G | title=Carnosine and carnosine-related antioxidants: a review | journal=Current Medicinal Chemistry | volume=12 | issue=20 | year=2005 | pages=2293–2315 | pmid=16181134 }}</ref> [[metformin]],<ref name=Rahbar&Figarola2003>{{Cite journal|pmid=14568010 |title=Novel inhibitors of advanced glycation endproducts |date=2013-03-25 |volume=419 |issue=1 |journal=Arch. Biochem. Biophys. |pages=63–79|doi=10.1016/j.abb.2003.08.009 | last1 = Rahbar | first1 = S | last2 = Figarola | first2 = JL}}</ref> [[pioglitazone]],<ref name=Rahbar&Figarola2003 /> and [[pentoxifylline]].<ref name=Rahbar&Figarola2003 />
Studies in rats and mice have found that [[natural phenol]]s such as [[resveratrol]] and [[curcumin]] can prevent the negative effects of the AGEs.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mizutani|first=K|author2=Ikeda, K|author3= Yamori, Y|title=Resveratrol inhibits AGEs-induced proliferation and collagen synthesis activity in vascular smooth muscle cells from stroke-prone spontaneously hypertensive rats.|journal=Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications|date=Jul 21, 2000|volume=274|issue=1|pages=61–7|pmid=10903896|doi=10.1006/bbrc.2000.3097}}</ref><ref name=" pmid = 24614199 ">{{cite journal | author = Tang Y | title = Curcumin eliminates the effect of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) on the divergent regulation of gene expression of receptors of AGEs by interrupting leptin signaling. | journal = Lab. Invest. | volume = 94 | issue = 5 |date= May 2014 | pmid = 24614199 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/labinvest.2014.42 | pages = 503–16 | doi=10.1038/labinvest.2014.42| pmc = 4006284 }}</ref>
Compounds that are thought to break some existing AGE crosslinks include [[Alagebrium]] (and related ALT-462, ALT-486, and ALT-946)<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.amjhyper.2004.08.022 | volume=17 | title=Advanced glycation end-product cross-link breakersA novel approach to cardiovascular pathologies related to the aging process | journal=American Journal of Hypertension | pages=S23–S30}}</ref> and [[N-phenacyl thiazolium bromide]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Vasan|first=S|author2=Zhang, X |author3=Zhang, X |author4=Kapurniotu, A |author5=Bernhagen, J |author6=Teichberg, S |author7=Basgen, J |author8=Wagle, D |author9=Shih, D |author10=Terlecky, I |author11=Bucala, R |author12=Cerami, A |author13=Egan, J |author14=Ulrich, P|title=An agent cleaving glucose-derived protein crosslinks in vitro and in vivo.|journal=Nature|date=Jul 18, 1996|volume=382|issue=6588|pages=275–8|pmid=8717046|doi=10.1038/382275a0}}</ref> One in vitro study shows that rosmarinic acid out performs the AGE breaking potential of ALT-711.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toukastress.jp/webj/article/2015/GS15-26.pdf | title=Evaluation in vitro of AGE-crosslinks breaking ability of rosmarinic acid | publisher=Glycative Stress Research | author1=Daniel Jean | author2=Maryse Pouligon | author3=Claude Dalle}}</ref>
[[File:Glucosepane.svg|thumb|right|Diagram of a glucosepane molecule]] There is, however, no agent known that can break down the most common AGE, [[glucosepane]], which appears 10 to 1,000 times more common in human tissue than any other cross-linking AGE.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Monnier, V. M. |author2=Mustata, G. T. |author3=Biemel, K. L. |author4=Reihl, O. |author5=Lederer, M. O. |author6=Zhenyu, D. |year=2005 |title=Cross-linking of the extracellular matrix by the maillard reaction in aging and [[diabetes]]: An update on "a puzzle nearing resolution" |journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences |volume=1043 |pages=533–544 |doi=10.1196/annals.1333.061 |pmid=16037276|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Furber, J.D. |year=2006 |title=Extracellular glycation crosslinks: Prospects for removal |journal=Rejuvenation Research |volume=9 |issue=2 |pages=274–278 |publisher=Elsevier Inc. |doi=10.1089/rej.2006.9.274 |pmid=16706655}}</ref>
Some chemicals, on the other hand, like [[aminoguanidine]], might limit the formation of AGEs by reacting with [[3-deoxyglucosone]].<ref name=MechanismOf/>
