{{flagicon|Libya|1951}} [[Hamid Hassy]] | commander2 = {{flagicon|Libya|1977}} '''[[Muammar Gaddafi]]{{KIA}}'''
{{flagicon|Libya|1977}} [[Mutassim Gaddafi]]{{KIA}}
{{flagicon|Libya|1977}} [[Abu-Bakr Yunis Jabr]]{{KIA}} | commander3 = | units1 = | units2 = | units3 = | strength1 = | strength2 = | strength3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | notes = | campaignbox = }} [[Muammar Gaddafi]], the deposed leader of [[Libya]], was captured and killed on 20 October 2011 during the [[Battle of Sirte (2011)|Battle of Sirte]]. Gaddafi was found hiding in a [[culvert]] west of Sirte and captured by [[National Transitional Council]] forces. He was killed shortly afterwards. The NTC initially claimed he died from injuries sustained in a firefight when loyalist forces attempted to free him, although a graphic video of his last moments show rebel fighters beating him and one of them sodomizing him with a bayonet{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/20/muammar-gaddafi-killing-witnesses |title=Gaddafi's last moments: 'I saw the hand holding the gun and I saw it fire' |author=Martin Chulov |website=theguardian.com |date=20 October 2012 |quote=one fighter crouched in the dirt behind the frightened captive and sodomised him with a bayonet |accessdate=24 September 2016}} before he was shot several times as he pleaded for his life.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2054344/Gaddafis-killers-trial-mob-execution-vow-Libyas-new-rulers.html|title=Gaddafi's killers will be put on trial over mob execution, vow Libya's new rulers|work=Daily Mail|date=28 October 2011|accessdate=28 October 2011|location=London|first=Sam|last=Greenhill}} == Events == After the [[Battle of Tripoli (2011)|fall of Tripoli]] to forces of the opposition [[National Transitional Council]] (NTC) in August 2011, Gaddafi and his family escaped the Libyan capital. He was widely rumoured to have taken refuge in the south of the country. In fact, though, Gaddafi had fled in a small convoy to [[Sirte]] on the day Tripoli fell. His son [[Mutassim Gaddafi]] followed in a second convoy.{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/world/132383263.html |work=Star Tribune |date=22 October 2011 |author=Kareem Fahim |accessdate=23 October 2011 |title=In his last days, Gadhafi survived on pasta and delusions |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111024203209/http://www.startribune.com/world/132383263.html |archivedate=24 October 2011 }} On 19 October 2011, Libya's prime minister [[Mahmoud Jibril]] said that the former leader was believed to be in the southern desert, reestablishing his government among pro-Gaddafi tribes in the region. By that point the NTC had just taken control of the pro-Gaddafi town of [[Bani Walid]] and were close to taking control of Gaddafi's home town, the tribal heartland of [[Sirte]] east of Tripoli.{{cite news|title=Gaddafi 'is recruiting fighters from other African countries'|agency=[[Associated Press]]|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=20 October 2011 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/oct/20/gaddafi-recruiting-fighters-african-countries |accessdate=21 October 2011}} According to most accounts, Gaddafi had been with heavily armed regime loyalists in several buildings in Sirte for several months as NTC forces took the city.{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/44971257/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/t/libyas-moammar-gadhafi-killed-hometown-battle/|title=Libya's Moammar Gadhafi killed in hometown battle|accessdate=20 October 2011|agency=Associated Press|publisher=MSNBC|date=18 October 2011}} [[Mansour Dhao]], a member of Gaddafi's inner circle and leader of the regime's [[People's Guard (Libya)|People's Guard]], said that Gaddafi was "very delusional" and complained about the lack of electricity and water. Attempts to persuade him to flee the country and give up power were ignored. As [[Battle of Sirte (2011)#Final assault|the last loyalist district of Sirte fell]], Gaddafi and other members of the government attempted to flee.{{Cite news|first1=Kareem|last1=Fahim|first2=Rick|last2=Gladstone|first3=Anthony|last3=Shadid|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/21/world/africa/qaddafi-is-killed-as-libyan-forces-take-surt.html|title=Violent End to an Era as Qaddafi Dies in Libya|work=The New York Times|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=29 October 2011|location=Misrata}} At around 01:30 local time (03:30 [[UTC]]) on 20 October 2011, Gaddafi, his army chief [[Abu-Bakr Yunis Jabr]], his security chief [[Mansour Dhao]], and a group of loyalists attempted to escape the violence in a convoy of 75 vehicles.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/23/world/africa/in-his-last-days-qaddafi-wearied-of-fugitives-life.html|work=The New York Times|first=Kareem|last=Fahim|title=In His Last Days, Qaddafi Wearied of Fugitive’s Life|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8839964/Col-Gaddafi-killed-convoy-bombed-by-drone-flown-by-pilot-in-Las-Vegas.html|title=Col Gaddafi killed-convoy bombed by drone flown by pilot in Las Vegas |work=The Telegraph |date=20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011|location=London|first=Thomas|last=Harding}} A [[Royal Air Force]] [[reconnaissance aircraft]] spotted the convoy moving at high speed, after NATO forces intercepted a satellite phone call made by Gaddafi.{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,793179,00.html|title=Wie die Nato Gaddafi jagte |language=German|work=Der Spiegel|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=21 October 2011}} NATO aircraft then fired on 21 of the vehicles, destroying one. A U.S. [[General Atomics MQ-1 Predator|Predator]] [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drone]] operated from a base near [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] fired the first missiles at the convoy, hitting its target about {{convert|3|km|0}} west of Sirte. Moments later, [[French Air Force]] [[Rafale]] fighter jets continued the bombing.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2051782/How-NATO-air-strike-finished-Gaddafi.html|title=How a NATO air strike finished off Gaddafi|work=Daily Mail|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=21 October 2011|location=London|first=David |last=Williams}} The NATO bombing immobilized much of the convoy and killed dozens of loyalist fighters. Following the first strike, some 11 vehicles broke away from the main group and continued moving south. A second NATO airstrike damaged or destroyed 20 of these vehicles.{{Contradict-inline|reason=How can 20 vehicles be destroyed when only 11 broke away?|date=August 2017}} Rebel units on the ground also struck the convoy.James Blitz and Hugh Carnegy. "[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/af362fc0-fb2e-11e0-8756-00144feab49a.html Confusion over Nato role in Gaddafi death]" (20 October 2011). ''Financial Times''. According to their statement, NATO was not aware at the time of the strike that Gaddafi was in the convoy. NATO stated that in accordance with [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973|Security Council Resolution 1973]], it does not target individuals but only military assets that pose a threat. NATO later learned, "from [[Open source intelligence|open sources]] and Allied [[Military intelligence|intelligence]]", that Gaddafi was in the convoy and that the strike likely contributed to his capture. After the airstrike, which destroyed the vehicle in front of Muammar Gaddafi's car, he and his son Mutassim, and former defence minister [[Abu-Bakr Yunis Jabr]], took shelter in a nearby house, which was then shelled by NTC forces. Mutassim then took 20 fighters and went to look for undamaged cars, having persuaded his father to come too. "The group belly-crawled to a sand berm," a UN report, released in March 2012 said, and then through two drainage pipes and set up a defensive position. One of Gaddafi's guards threw a grenade at advancing rebels on the road above, but it hit a concrete wall above the pipes and fell in front of Gaddafi. The guard tried to pick it up, but it exploded, killing both the guard and Yunis Jabr.{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/03/02/libya-gaddafi-idINDEE8210HI20120302| agency=Reuters|title=Gaddafi wanted to stage last stand in desert - U.N. report|date=2 March 2012}} ===Capture and death=== Gaddafi took refuge in a large [[Culvert|drainage pipe]] with several loyalist bodyguards. A nearby group of NTC fighters opened fire, wounding Gaddafi with gunshots to his leg and back. According to one unnamed NTC fighter, one of Gaddafi's own loyalists also shot him, apparently to spare him from being captured.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/middle-east-live/2011/oct/20/gaddafi-killed-sirte-falls-live|title=Gaddafi killed as Sirte falls|work=The Guardian|location=UK|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011 |first=Adam |last=Gabbatt}}David Martin – [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/10/20/eveningnews/main20123436.shtml "Who shot Qaddafi? Was it his own bodyguards?"] – ''CBS News'' – 20 October 2011. Retrieved 21 October 2011. It is unclear if NATO aircraft were involved in helping secure Gaddafi's capture by Libyan forces on the ground. A group of rebels approached the pipe where Gaddafi was hiding and ordered him to come out, which he slowly did. He was then dragged up to his feet as rebels shouted "Muammar, Muammar!"{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/20/muammar-gaddafi-killing-witnesses|title=Gaddafi's last moments: 'I saw the hand holding the gun and I saw it fire'|author=Martin Chulov|work=the Guardian}} However, a UN report released in March 2012 revealed a different account of Gaddafi's capture. Gaddafi was wounded by grenade fragmentation, from a grenade thrown by one of his own men, that bounced off a wall and fell in front of Gaddafi, that shredded his [[flak jacket]]. He sat on the floor dazed and in shock, bleeding from a wound in the left temple. Then one of his group waved a white turban in surrender. Gaddafi was killed shortly afterwards. There are conflicting reports; according to one report, Gaddafi said "Please don't shoot!" prior to being shot,{{cite news|title="Don't shoot": Qaddafi's last moments|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20123183-503543.html|accessdate=20 October 2011|newspaper=CBS News|date=20 October 2011}} and when questioned by Misratan rebel fighters about the damage done to [[Misrata]] by his forces, denied any involvement, and begged his captors not to hit him or kill him. One fighter demanded Gaddafi stand up, but he struggled to do so.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15889840|date=28 November 2011|accessdate=8 December 2011|publisher=BBC News|title=Libyan fighter: I spoke to Gaddafi before he died}} Gaddafi can be heard in one video saying "God forbids this" and "Do you know right from wrong?" when being shouted at by his captors.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/23/us-libya-gaddafi-finalhours-idUSTRE79M02W20111023|agency=Reuters|title=Clues to Gaddafi's death concealed from public view|date=23 October 2011}}{{cite news|author=Raymond A. Schroth|url=http://www.americamagazine.org/blog/entry.cfm?entry_id=4699 |title=Readings: Any Hope for Libya?|publisher=America Magazine|date=27 October 2011|accessdate=9 December 2012}} In a video of his arrest he can be seen draped on the hood of a car, held by rebel fighters.{{cite web |url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=598_1319129108|title=Gaddafie Captured alive then Executed footage. |publisher=Liveleak|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/20/us-libya-gaddafi-finalhours-idUSTRE79J5Q720111020|title=Gaddafi's death – who pulled the trigger?|agency=Reuters|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}} A senior NTC official said that no order was given to execute Gaddafi. According to another NTC source, "they captured him alive and while he was being taken away, they beat him and then they killed him". Mahmoud Jibril gave an alternative account, stating that "when the car was moving it was caught in crossfire between the revolutionaries and Gaddafi forces in which he was hit by a bullet in the head."{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15389550|title=Muammar Gaddafi killed in Libya|publisher=BBC|date=20 October 2011}} Several videos related to the death were broadcast by news channels and circulated via the Internet. The first shows footage of Gaddafi alive, his face and shirt bloodied, stumbling and being dragged toward an ambulance by armed militants chanting "[[Takbir|God is great]]" in [[Arabic]]. The video shows Gaddafi being sodomized with a bayonet.{{cite news|title=GlobalPost: Qaddafi apparently sodomized after capture|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20124758-503543/globalpost-qaddafi-apparently-sodomized-after-capture/ |quote=a GlobalPost analysis of video footage suggests a Libyan fighter sodomized the former dictator after he was captured near Sirte. |publisher=CBS |accessdate=23 September 2016}}{{cite journal |author=Seymour Hersh |authorlink=Seymour Hersh |url=https://www.lrb.co.uk/v38/n01/seymour-m-hersh/military-to-military |title=Military to Military: Seymour M. Hersh on US intelligence sharing in the Syrian war |quote=He also echoed a view held by some in the Pentagon when he alluded to a collateral factor behind Russia’s decision to launch airstrikes in support of the Syrian army on 30 September: Putin’s desire to prevent Assad from suffering the same fate as Gaddafi. He had been told that Putin had watched a video of Gaddafi’s savage death three times, a video that shows him being sodomised with a bayonet. |work=[[London Review of Books]] |volume=38 |number=1 |pages=11–14 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/1028/1224306622302.html|title=Gadafy's killers will be tried, claims NTC|last=Chulov|first=Martin|date=28 October 2011|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=23 September 2016|quote=The footage, including images of a wounded Gadafy being sodomised with what looked like a bayonet, caused widespread revulsion outside the country.}} Another shows Gaddafi, stripped to the waist, suffering from an apparent gunshot wound to the head, and in a pool of blood, together with jubilant fighters firing automatic weapons in the air. A third video, posted on YouTube, shows fighters "hovering around his lifeless-looking body, posing for photographs and yanking his limp head up and down by the hair."{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/10/2011102014201566639.html|title=Footage shows Gaddafi's bloodied body|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}} Another video shows him being stripped naked and verbally abused by his captors.{{cite news |author=Faraway |url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/11173097-exclusive-video-gaddafi-stripped-naked-by-rebels-before-his-death |title=(Exclusive Video) Gaddafi stripped naked by rebels before his death |publisher=All Voices |date=26 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |accessdate=9 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215054832/http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/11173097-exclusive-video-gaddafi-stripped-naked-by-rebels-before-his-death |archivedate=15 February 2012 }} It was stated in an October 2012 report that Gaddafi had not been killed in crossfire during his capture. He may have been executed without trial, along with 66 others, including one of his sons.{{cite web|title=Report: Libyan militias executed dozens, possibly including Gadhafi|url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2012/10/17/report-libyan-militias-executed-dozens-possibly-including-gadhafi/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=18 October 2012}} Gaddafi's body was taken to [[Misrata]], where a doctor's examination disclosed he had been shot in the head and abdomen.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/20/us-libya-idUSTRE79F1FK20111020|title=Gaddafi killed in hometown, Libya eyes future|agency=Reuters|date=20 October 2011|author=Barry Malone}} ==== Public display ==== The interim Libyan authorities decided to keep Gaddafi's body "for a few days", NTC oil minister [[Ali Tarhouni]] said, "to make sure that everybody knows he is dead."{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15398866 |publisher= BBC |title= Libya delays burial plans for Muammar Gaddafi |date= 21 October 2011 |accessdate= 21 October 2011}} The body was moved to an industrial freezer where members of the public were permitted to view it {{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/21/us-libya-idUSTRE79F1FK20111021 |title= Gaddafi, in meat locker, still divides Libya |agency= Reuters |date= 21 October 2011 |accessdate= 21 October 2011}} until 24 October. Video shows Gaddafi's body on display in the center of an emptied public freezer in Misrata.{{cite news |last= Kim |first= Kyle |title= Gaddafi's body "packed in shopping center freezer" (VIDEO) (GRAPHIC) |url= http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/middle-east/111021/gaddafis-body-packed-shopping-center-freezer-ap-reports-pho |accessdate= 5 January 2012 |newspaper= GlobalPost |date= 21 October 2011}} Some people traveled hundreds of kilometres to see proof that Gaddafi was dead; one said, "God made the pharaoh as an example to the others. If he had been a good man, we would have buried him. But he chose this destiny for himself."{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/24/us-libya-idUSTRE79F1FK20111024 |title= Libya "liberated" but Gaddafi still unburied |agency=[[Reuters]] |date= 24 October 2011 |accessdate= 24 October 2011}} One reporter observed gunshot residue on the wounds, consistent with shots at close range. Gaddafi's body was displayed alongside that of his son, [[Mutassim Gaddafi]], who also died in the custody of Misratan fighters after his capture in Sirte on 20 October. The younger Gaddafi's body was removed from the refrigerator for burial at the same time as his father's on 24 October.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2053110/Gaddafi-burial-Dictator-son-Mutassims-dead-bodies-unmarked-grave.html |title= Ignominious end for dictator Gaddafi as he is buried with his son Mutassim in unmarked desert grave at dawn |work= Daily Mail |date= 26 October 2011 |accessdate= 26 October 2011 |location= London}} ====Burial==== Although an NTC spokesman said Gaddafi's body would be returned to his family with a directive to keep his burial site secret after an [[autopsy]] had determined the cause of death, the semi-autonomous military council in Misrata said it would be buried quickly instead, vetoing the idea of an autopsy.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Gaddafi-family-demands-body-NATO-ends-Libya-war/articleshow/10452972.cms|work=The Times of India|title=Muammar Gaddafi family demands body, Nato ends Libya war|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-oct-22-2011-2041|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=22 October 2011}} [[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] called for an independent autopsy and an investigation into how Gaddafi died,{{cite news|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/10/21/does_it_really_matter_if_qaddafi_was_executed|work=Foreign Policy|first=Blake|last=Hounshell|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011|title=Does it really matter if Qaddafi was executed?}} but Jibril said neither step was necessary.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8843756/Libya-to-greet-dawn-of-new-era.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011|title=Libya to greet dawn of new era|first=Damien|last=McElroy|location=London}} On 25 October, NTC representatives announced that Gaddafi's body had been buried in an unknown location in the desert early that morning, together with those of his son [[Mutassim Gaddafi]] and the regime's defense minister [[Abu-Bakr Yunis Jabr]].{{cite news|title=Gaddafi buried in unknown location, reports say|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/oct/25/muammar-gaddafi-buried-libya|work=The Guardian|date=25 October 2011|accessdate=25 October 2011|location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-10-25/gaddafi-buried-in-secret-location-at-dawn/3600098|title=Gaddafi buried in secret location at dawn|publisher=ABC News|date=25 October 2011|accessdate=25 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/10/2011102573231228800.html|title=NTC says Gaddafi buried in secret grave|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=25 October 2011|accessdate=25 October 2011}} A Dubai-based satellite TV channel [[Al Aan TV]] showed amateur footage of the funeral taking place at an unknown location where Islamic prayers were read.{{cite news|last=Mousa|first=Jenan|script-title=ar:تجهيز جثمان القذافي للدفن في الصحراء الليبية - صور حصرية|url=http://akhbar.alaan.tv/video/alaan-reports/Processing-Gaddafi-body-burial-Libyan-desert/|accessdate=28 October 2011|newspaper=Akhbar Alaan|language=Arabic}}{{cite news|title=Gaddafi Funeral Video: Footage Claims To Show Secret Ceremony|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/26/gaddafi-funeral-video_n_1032728.html|accessdate=28 October 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=26 October 2011|first=Clare|last=Richardson}} Libya's Minister for Information [[Mahmoud Shammam]] said that a [[fatwa]] had declared that "Gaddafi should not be buried in Muslim cemeteries and should not be buried in a known place to avoid any sedition."{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15441867 |title=Col Gaddafi 'buried in secret, desert grave at dawn'|publisher=BBC|date=25 October 2011|accessdate=25 October 2011}} ===Foreign involvement=== ====United States==== {{further|American involvement in the 2011 Libyan Civil War}} Moments after it was reported that Gaddafi was killed, [[Fox News]] published an article titled "U.S. Drone Involved in Final Qaddafi Strike, as Obama Heralds Regime's 'End'",{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/10/20/obama-qaddafi-death-ends-long-and-painful-chapter-in-libya.html|title=U.S. Drone Involved in Final Qaddafi Strike, as Obama Heralds Regime's 'End'|work=Fox News|accessdate=16 May 2016}} noting that a U.S. Predator drone was involved in the airstrike on Gaddafi's convoy in the moments before his death. An anonymous US official subsequently described their policy in hindsight as "lead[ing] from behind".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-15393497|title=Gaddafi killed: A new kind of US foreign policy success|work=BBC News|accessdate=16 May 2016}} Because Libyan rebels had consistently told American government officials that they did not want overt foreign military assistance in toppling Gaddafi, [[Covert operation|covert military assistance]] was used (including arms shipments to opposition). The plan following Gaddafi's death was to immediately begin flowing humanitarian assistance to eastern Libya and later western Libya, as the symbolism would be critically important. US sources stressed it as important that they would "not allow [[Turkey]], [[Italy]] and others to steal a march on it".{{cite web|url=https://wikileaks.org/clinton-emails/emailid/6604|title=WikiLeaks|publisher=|accessdate=16 May 2016}} == Concurrent capture or death of relatives and associates == National Transitional Council officials also announced that one of Gaddafi's sons, [[Mutassim Gaddafi]], once the Libyan national security advisor, was killed in Sirte the same day. A video later surfaced showing Mutassim's body lying in an ambulance.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gd0_S25NlIA&feature=youtube_gdata_player&skipcontrinter=1 |title=Mutassim's body |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=22 October 2011}} A video aired on [[Arrai TV|Al Arrai television]] showed Mutassim alive and talking to his captors. The circumstances of his death are unclear. Another son, [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]], was captured almost a month after his father's death, whilst trying to flee to Niger.{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/20111119111936535209.html |title=Saif al-Islam Gaddafi arrested in Libya |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=19 November 2011 |accessdate=9 December 2012}} Footage had emerged earlier on 20 October of the body of Gaddafi's defence minister, [[Abu-Bakr Yunis Jabr]]. Abdul Hakim Al Jalil, the commander of the NTC's 11th brigade, stated that former Gaddafi spokesman [[Moussa Ibrahim]] had been captured near Sirte. Reports indicate that Ahmed Ibrahim, one of Gaddafi's cousins, was also captured.{{Cite news | title = Muammar Gaddafi killed as Sirte falls | publisher=Al Jazeera | date = 20 October 2011 | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/10/20111020111520869621.html}} == Subsequent events == === Calls for investigation === Numerous organizations, including the [[United Nations]] and the U.S. and UK governments, have called for an investigation of the exact circumstances of Gaddafi's death,{{cite web|url=http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=156787|title=Calls grow for full investigation into Gaddafi’s death|author=Karin Laub|work=Business Day|location=South Africa|date=24 October 2011}} amid controversy that it was an [[extrajudicial killing]] and a [[war crime]].{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-10-22/call-for-probe-into-gaddafi-death/3595198/?site=melbourne|title=Pressure grows for Gaddafi death investigation|date=22 October 2011|publisher=ABC News}}{{cite web|title=UN calls for probe into Gaddafi's death|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/10/20111021235116164421.html|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=25 October 2011|date=22 October 2011}} The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Navi Pillay, had said there should be a full investigation.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-15390980|title=Muammar Gaddafi: How he died|author=|work=BBC News|location=|date=31 October 2011}} The [[UN Human Rights Office]] spokesperson said that he expects the UN commission already investigating potential human rights abuse in Libya would look into the case.{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/10/20111021235116164421.html |title=UN calls for probe into Gaddafi's death |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=22 October 2011 |accessdate=22 October 2011}} [[Waheed Burshan]], a member of the NTC, said that an investigation should happen.{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/10/20111022133513323321.html |title=Doubts cast on official Gaddafi death account |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=22 October 2011 |accessdate=22 October 2011}} On 24 October 2011, the NTC announced that it had ordered an investigation in response to the international calls{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/10/2011102413358850809.html |title=Libya's NTC orders probe into Gaddafi killing |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |date=24 October 2011 |accessdate=24 October 2011}} and that it would prosecute the killers if the investigation showed he died after his capture.{{cite news |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/north/Libya-Vows-to-Prosecute-Gadhafi-Killers-132700743.html|title=Libya Vows to Prosecute Gadhafi Killers |publisher= [[Voice of America]] |date=27 October 2011 |accessdate=31 October 2011}} Almost a year later, on 17 October 2012, new evidence was revealed by [[Human Rights Watch]] showing that mass killings occurred at the site of Gaddafi's death.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/10/16/libya-new-proof-mass-killings-gaddafi-death-site|title=Libya: New Proof of Mass Killings at Gaddafi Death Site|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=17 October 2012}} === Regional ramifications === In its immediate aftermath, the controversial killing of Gaddafi was thought to have significant implications in the Middle East, as a critical part of the wider '[[Arab Spring]]'.{{cite news|url=http://www.periscopepost.com/2011/10/arab-spring-domino-effect-gaddafi-is-gone-will-syrias-al-assad-be-the-next-arab-autocrat-toppled/|title=Arab Spring domino effect: Gaddafi is gone, will Syria’s al-Assad be the next Arab autocrat toppled?|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=24 June 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8839143/Arab-Spring-timeline-of-the-African-and-Middle-East-rebellions.html|title=Arab Spring: timeline of the African and Middle East rebellions|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=24 June 2012|location=London}} Former CIA analyst [[Bruce Riedel]] speculated that the death would intensify protesting in [[Syrian uprising (2011–present)|Syria]] and [[2011–2012 Yemeni revolution|Yemen]], and French officials stated that because of this they were "watching the [[2010–2012 Algerian protests|Algerian situation]]".[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/10/20/qaddafi-s-death-send-clear-message-to-middle-east-dictators-run-will-algiers-be-next.html "Which Middle East Dictator Is Going Down Next?"] World News – ''The Daily Beast -'' 20 October 2011 – 20 October 2011. ===Vengeance=== Omran Shaban, the Misrata fighter who discovered Gaddafi in the drain pipe and who had posed in photos with his golden gun, was captured by [[Gaddafi loyalism after the 2011 Libyan Civil War|Green Resistance]] soldiers in Bani Walid. He was then paralysed and severely tortured. The interim president of Libya secured his release but he died some days later from his wounds in France.{{cite news|author=George Grant |url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/09/25/libyan-revolutionary-who-captured-qaddafi-dies-in-paris/ |title=Libyan revolutionary who captured Qaddafi dies in Paris |publisher=[[Libya Herald]] |date=25 September 2012 |accessdate=9 December 2012}}{{subscription needed}} {{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/26/omran-shaban-dead_n_1915680.html|title=Omran Shaban Dead: Rebel Who Helped Catch Gaddafi Dies After Being Captured And Tortured|date=26 September 2012|work=[[The WorldPost]]|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=6 September 2014}} ==Domestic reactions== Prime Minister [[Mahmoud Jibril]] said he wished Gaddafi had remained alive so he could be tried for [[crimes against humanity]],{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-20124313/autopsy-qaddafi-was-killed-by-shot-to-head/|work=CBS News|date=23 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011|title=Autopsy: Qaddafi was killed by shot to head}} saying he had wanted to serve as Gaddafi's prosecutor,{{cite news|url=http://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/86293,news-comment,news-politics,-libyan-prime-minister-mahmoud-jibril-i-wish-gaddafi-had-not-been-killed|work=The First Post|title=Libyan PM: I wish Gaddafi had not been killed|date=23 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011}} but now that he was dead, Libya would need a meticulous plan for the transition to democracy.{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/scotland-on-sunday/international/remember_years_of_agony_in_libya_says_mahmoud_jibril_1_1925839|work=The Scotsman|title=Remember years of agony in Libya, says Mahmoud Jibril|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011}} The unelected head of state said, "Our forces' resistance to Gaddafi ended well, with the help of God." He declared Libya to be "liberated" at a ceremony in [[Benghazi]] on 23 October, three days after Gaddafi's death.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/f459749a-fd86-11e0-a9db-00144feabdc0.html|title=Libya declares liberation after Gaddafi's death|date=23 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011|first=Borzou|last=Daragahi|work=Financial Times}} NTC official [[Ali Tarhouni]] said on 22 October that he had instructed the military council in Misrata to keep Gaddafi's body preserved for several days in a commercial freezer "to make sure that everybody knows he is dead".{{cite news|url=http://dailynews.co.zw/index.php/news/34-news/4813-libya-delays-burial-plans-for-dictator.html|publisher=BBC News|title=Libya delays burial plans for dictator|date=22 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011}} Two days later, Tarhouni admitted that there had been human rights abuses in the Battle of Sirte, which he said the NTC condemned, and claimed the Executive Board "did not want to put an end to that tyrant's life before bringing him to trial and making him answer questions that have always haunted Libyans".{{cite news|url=http://www.magharebia.com/cocoon/awi/xhtml1/en_GB/features/awi/features/2011/10/26/feature-01|work=Magharebia|title=NTC vows to probe rights abuses, control arms|date=26 October 2011|accessdate=26 October 2011}} A spokesman for the Misrata military council, [[Fathi Bashagha]], stated the council was confident Gaddafi was dead and that he had died of wounds sustained during fighting before his capture.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2011/s3345172.htm|publisher=ABC News|title=Misurata militia says it still has Gaddafi's body|first=Peter|last=Cave|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=23 October 2011}} [[Saadi Gaddafi]], one of Muammar Gaddafi's surviving sons in exile in [[Niger]], said through an attorney that he was "shocked and outraged by vicious brutality" toward his father and his brother, [[Mutassim Gaddafi]], and that the killing showed that the new Libyan leadership could not be trusted to hold fair trials.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/liveblog/libya-oct-24-2011-0002|work=Al Jazeera Blogs|title=Sun, 23 Oct 2011, 21:02 GMT+3 - Libya|accessdate=23 October 2011}} ==International reactions== {{main|International reactions to the death of Muammar Gaddafi}} {{see also|International reactions to the 2011 military intervention in Libya}} Many leaders and foreign ministers of [[Europe]]an countries, as well as fellow [[Western world|Western]] countries like [[Australia]], [[Canada]], and the [[United States]], made statements hailing Gaddafi's death as a positive development for Libya. The [[city-state]] of [[Vatican City]] responded to the event by declaring it recognised the [[National Transitional Council]] as Libya's legitimate government.{{cite news|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/nation-world/world-looks-warily-to-1206420.html|work=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|title=World looks warily to Libya's future post-Gadhafi|first=Raphael|last=Satter|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}} World leaders such as [[Italy|Italian]] Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]],{{cite news |title=News of Gadhafi's Death Met With Relief |agency=[[Associated Press]] [[Thomson Reuters|Reuters]] |work=[[Voice of America|VOA News]] |date=20 October 2011 |url= http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Reports-of-Gadhafis-Death-Met-with-Relief--132240193.html |accessdate=21 October 2011}} and Australian Prime Minister [[Julia Gillard]]{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-10-21/gillard-abbott-on-gaddafi-death/3590956|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|title=Gaddafi death brings 'relief' to Libya: Gillard|date=21 October 2011|accessdate=22 October 2011}} suggested that the death of Gaddafi meant the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]] was over. Some officials, such as [[United Kingdom|UK]] Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]], expressed disappointment that Gaddafi was not brought back alive and allowed to stand trial.David S. Cloud." [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2011/10/libya-nato-airstrikes.html NATO commander expected to recommend ending Libya airstrikes]" (20 October 2011). The United States' Secretary of State at the time, Hillary Clinton, laughingly stated "We came. We saw. He died."Hillary Clinton."[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6DXDU48RHLU We Came, We Saw, He Died]" Reaction from the governments of countries including [[Cuba]],{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/24/us-cuba-castro-idUSTRE79N2YC20111024 |title=Fidel Castro calls NATO "brutal" for Libya role |publisher=Reuters |date=24 October 2011 |accessdate=9 December 2012}} [[Russia]],{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-10-27/putin-disgust-at-gaddafi-coverage/3602748 |title=Putin 'disgusted' at Gaddafi coverage |publisher=ABC News Australia |date=27 October 2011 |accessdate=9 December 2012}} [[Venezuela]],{{cite news| url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-10-21/americas/world_americas_venezuela-chavez-gadhafi_1_moammar-gadhafi-libyan-rebels-libyan-leader | publisher=CNN | title=Gadhafi's friend to the death, Chavez calls Libyan leader 'a martyr' | date=20 October 2011}} [[Nicaragua]],{{cite news|author= |url=http://en.mercopress.com/2012/01/12/nicaragua-s-ortega-condemned-killing-of-gaddafi-and-offered-a-prayer-for-hussein |title=Nicaragua’s Ortega condemned killing of Gaddafi and offered a prayer for Hussein |publisher=MercoPress |date=12 January 2012 |accessdate=9 December 2012}} was negative. [[Venezuela]]n President [[Hugo Chávez]] described the former Libyan leader's death as an "[[assassination]]" and an "outrage",{{cite news|title=As it happened: Libya's Col Gaddafi killed|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15387872|accessdate=20 October 2011|publisher=BBC |date=20 October 2011}} and [[Nicaragua]]n President [[Daniel Ortega]] later called his killing a "crime" during his inauguration on 10 January 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Ortega-urges-Israel-to-destroy-nuclear-arms|title=Ortega urges Israel to destroy 'nuclear arms'|author=|date=|work=The Jerusalem Post - JPost.com|accessdate=19 March 2016}} Officials of [[Iran]] showed considerably diverse reactions.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/25/us-libya-ahmadinejad-idUSTRE79O2QK20111025 | agency=Reuters | title=Iran's Ahmadinejad says West set to plunder Libya | date=25 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2011/10/21/tehran/|title=Иран похвалил ливийцев за устранение Каддафи|author=|date=|work=lenta.ru|accessdate=19 March 2016}} The video reportedly left a particularly strong, and consequential, impression on Russia's [[Vladimir Putin]]. A senior diplomat who had served at the US embassy in Moscow under the Obama administration reportedly claimed that "Putin had been appalled by Gaddafi’s fate"[[Seymour Hersh]], [http://www.lrb.co.uk/v38/n01/seymour-m-hersh/military-to-military 'Military to Military,'] [[London Review of Books]], Vol. 38 No. 1,7 January 2016 pp.11-14. Retrieved 13 May 2016. to the extent that "Putin had watched a video of Gaddafi’s savage death three times, a video that shows him being sodomised with a bayonet." Referring to the U.S. coalition's lobbying efforts for the airstrikes at the U.N., the U.S. diplomat is quoted as saying that a later U.S. intelligence assessment concluded that "Putin blamed himself for letting Gaddafi go, for not playing a strong role behind the scenes" and that the video may have even influenced Putin's decision to support Syrian President Bashar al-Assad during the Syrian civil war since "Putin believed that unless he got engaged Bashar would suffer the same fate – mutilated – and he’d see the destruction of his allies in Syria." Putin also lashed out at the [[United States|U.S.]] for the illegal killing of Gaddafi and asked "They showed to the whole world how he (Gaddafi) was killed; there was blood all over. Is that what they call a democracy?"{{cite news|author=Deng Shasha |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2011-12/15/c_131309049.htm |title=Putin slams U.S. on Gaddafi killing |publisher=Xinhua |date=15 December 2011 |accessdate=9 December 2012}} ===NATO=== {{main|International reactions to the death of Muammar Gaddafi#Intergovernmental organizations}} Immediately after Gaddafi's death, [[NATO]] released a statement denying it knew beforehand that Gaddafi was travelling in the convoy it struck. Admiral [[James G. Stavridis]], NATO's top officer, said the death of Gaddafi meant that NATO would likely wind down [[Operation Unified Protector|its operations in Libya]]."[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-20123633/nato-commander-to-recommend-libya-mission-end/ NATO commander to recommend Libya mission end]" (21 October 2011). Associated Press. [[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]], the NATO secretary-general, said NATO would "terminate [its] mission in coordination with the United Nations and the National Transitional Council". {{Portalbar|Libya|Death|War|2010s}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Muammar Gaddafi}} {{Libyan civil war}} [[Category:Filmed assassinations|Gaddafi, Muammar]] [[Category:Libyan Civil War (2011)|Gaddafi, Muammar]] [[Category:Airstrikes|Gaddafi, Muammar]] [[Category:Deaths by person|Gaddafi, Muammar]] [[Category:Muammar Gaddafi]] [[Category:October 2011 events]]

Murderer sentenced to life in prison {{start date and age|2017|04|18}} | residence = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | other_names = | known_for = One of the first missing-child cases to have a photo appear on a milk carton | home_town = Manhattan, New York, United States | parents = Stanley Patz
Julie Patz }} '''Etan Kalil Patz''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|eɪ|t|ɑː|n|_|ˈ|p|eɪ|t|s}}; October 9, 1972 – May 25, 1979;http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2012/05/etan_patz_was_strangled_to_dea.html [[declared death in absentia|declared legally dead]] in 2001) was an American boy who was six years old on May 25, 1979, when he disappeared on his way to his [[school bus]] stop in the [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]] neighborhood of [[Lower Manhattan]]. His disappearance helped launch the [[Child abduction|missing children movement]], which included new legislation and new methods for tracking down missing children. Several years after he disappeared, Patz was one of the first children to be profiled on the "[[photo on a milk carton]]" campaigns of the early 1980s.{{cite news|last1=Toppo|first1=Greg|title=Etan Patz – boy on the milk carton – gets justice: Man convicted in 1979 murder|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/02/14/nyc-jury-reaches-verdict-etan-patz-murder-case/97894676/|accessdate=March 26, 2018|work=[[USA Today]]|date=February 14, 2017}} In 1983, President [[Ronald Reagan]] designated May 25—the anniversary of Etan's disappearance—as [[National Missing Children's Day]] in the United States. Decades later, it was determined that Etan had been abducted and murdered the same day that he went missing. The case was reopened in 2010 by the [[New York County District Attorney|Manhattan District Attorney]]'s office. In 2012, the [[FBI]] excavated the basement of the alleged crime scene near the Patz residence but discovered no new evidence. Pedro Hernandez—a suspect who confessed— was charged and indicted later that year on charges of second-degree murder and first-degree kidnapping. In 2014, the case went through a series of hearings to determine whether or not Hernandez's statements before he received his [[Miranda warning|Miranda rights]] were legally admissible at trial. His trial began in January 2015 and ended in a mistrial that May, when one of the 12 jurors held out. The retrial began on October 19, 2016, and concluded on February 14, 2017, after nine days of deliberations, when the jury found Hernandez guilty of [[murder]] and [[kidnapping]].{{cite web|title=Statement from John F. Clark on the verdict in the Etan Patz trial|url=http://www.missingkids.org/vnr|website=missingkids.org|publisher=[[National Center for Missing & Exploited Children]]|accessdate=February 15, 2017|date=February 14, 2017|archiveurl=|archivedate=February 15, 2017}} Hernandez was sentenced to 25-years-to-life in prison on April 18, 2017. Hernandez will not be eligible for [[parole]] for 25 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/news/national/man-25-years-1979-case-missing-boy-etan-patz-article-1.3067605|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419013451/http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/news/national/man-25-years-1979-case-missing-boy-etan-patz-article-1.3067605|archivedate=April 19, 2017|title=Man gets 25 years in 1979 case of missing boy Etan Patz|date=April 18, 2017|publisher=NY Daily News|accessdate=July 16, 2017}} ==Disappearance== On the morning of May 25, 1979, Etan left his [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]] apartment at 113 Prince Street by himself for the first time, planning to walk two blocks to board a school bus at [[West Broadway]] and Prince Street.{{cite news |author= |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1979/05/27/120970566.pdf |title=Police and Neighbors Join in a SoHo Search For Missing Schoolboy |date=May 27, 1979 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=May 8, 2015 }} He was wearing a black "Future Flight Captain" pilot cap, a blue corduroy jacket, blue jeans and blue [[sneakers]] with fluorescent stripes. He never got on the bus.{{cite news |last=Kihss |first=Peter |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1979/05/30/111031936.pdf |title=Boy Missing From SoHo Was on Own First Time |date=May 30, 1979 |newspaper=The New York Times |quote=He never made the last half block ... to the corner where another mother waited for him until 8:20 ... |accessdate=May 8, 2015 }} At school, Etan's teacher noticed his absence but did not report it to the principal. When Etan did not return home after school, his mother Julie called the police. At first, detectives considered the Patzes to be possible suspects but quickly determined they had no involvement. An intense search began that evening, using nearly 100 police officers and a team of [[bloodhound]]s. The search continued for weeks. Neighbors and police canvassed the city and placed missing-child posters featuring Etan's portrait, but this resulted in few leads.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-18188241 |title=Etan Patz death: Man confesses to NYC killing in 1979 |date=May 25, 2012 |work=BBC News |accessdate=May 25, 2012}}{{cite news|author=Ramirez, Jessica |date=January 29, 2007|title=The Abductions That Changed America|work=[[Newsweek]]|pages=54–55}} Etan's father Stanley was a professional photographer and had a collection of photographs he had taken of his son. His photos of Etan were printed on countless missing-child posters and milk cartons. They were also projected on screens in [[Times Square]].{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/etan-patz-missing-boy-case-reopened-31-years/story?id=10749565 |title=Etan Patz Case Reopened 31 Years Later|last1=Berman |first1=Thomas |last2=Sher |first2=Lauren |date=May 26, 2010 |accessdate=July 16, 2011 |work=[[ABC News]]}} ==Accusations against Jose Ramos== Assistant [[United States Attorney]] Stuart R. GraBois received the case in 1985 and identified Jose Antonio Ramos, a convicted [[child sexual abuse]]r who had been a friend of Etan's former babysitters, as the primary suspect. In 1982, multiple boys had accused Ramos of trying to lure them into a [[Storm drain|drain pipe]] in the area where Ramos was living. When police searched the drain pipe, they found photographs of Ramos and young boys who resembled Etan. GraBois eventually found out that Ramos had been in custody in [[Pennsylvania]] in connection with an unrelated child molestation case. In 1990, GraBois was deputized as a deputy state attorney general in Pennsylvania to help prosecute a case against Ramos for sexually abusing children and to obtain further information about Etan's case. When first questioned by GraBois, Ramos stated that, on the day when Etan disappeared, he had taken a young boy back to his apartment to [[rape]] him. Ramos said that he was "90 percent sure" it was the boy whom he later saw on television. However, Ramos did not use Etan's name. He also claimed he had "put the boy on a subway".{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} In 1991, while Ramos was incarcerated, a [[Informant#Jailhouse informants|jailhouse informant]] told GraBois and FBI agent Mary Galligan that Ramos had told him he knew what had happened to Etan. Ramos even drew a map of Etan's school bus route, indicating that he knew that Etan's bus stop was the third one on the route. In a special feature on missing children, the ''[[New York Post]]'' reported on October 21, 1999, that Ramos was the prime suspect in Etan's disappearance.{{cite news|author=Weiss, Murray (October 21, 1999|title=Where are these kids? NYPD creates a new squad to investigate unsolved missing kid cases|work=New York Post|page=32}} "Investigators now believe a pedophile in prison in Pennsylvania for abusing two children there is the prime suspect in Patz's disappearance, but he has never been charged in the New York case." Accessed via [[LexisNexis]]. Ramos had been known by the Patz family and was the prime suspect all along, but in the early 1980s authorities were unable to prosecute Ramos.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} Etan's body was never found; he was declared [[legally dead]] in 2001. Stan and Julie Patz pursued and won a [[civil case]] against Ramos in 2004.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/05/nyregion/judge-rules-that-convicted-molester-now-prison-responsible-for-etan-patz-s-death.html|title=Judge Rules That a Convicted Molester, Now in Prison, Is Responsible for Etan Patz's Death|last=Saulny|first=Susan|date=May 5, 2004|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=May 9, 2015}} They were awarded a symbolic sum of $2 million, which they have [[judgment proof|never collected]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Etan-Patz-Case-SoHo-Search-FBI-NYPD-148088675.html|title=FBI, NYPD Resume Search for Etan Patz, Boy Who Disappeared in 1979|last=Prokupecz|first=Shimon|date=April 19, 2012|work=[[NBC]]|accessdate=April 19, 2012}} Ramos has never been criminally prosecuted for the murder of Etan. Every year, on Etan's birthday and the anniversary of his disappearance, Stan Patz sent Ramos a copy of his son's missing-child poster. On the back, he typed the same message: "What did you do to my little boy?"{{cite news |url=http://nymag.com/news/features/56441/ |title=What happened to Etan Patz |last=Cohen|first=Lisa R. |date=May 3, 2009 |magazine=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |accessdate=July 16, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/14/a-new-horror-recalls-another/ |title=A New Horror Recalls Another |last=Haberman |first=Clyde |date=July 14, 2011 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=July 16, 2011}} Ramos has denied that he killed Etan. He served a 20-year prison sentence in the [[State Correctional Institution – Dallas|State Correctional Institution]] in [[Dallas, Pennsylvania]], for child molestation. He was released from prison on November 7, 2012. Soon after his release he was arrested on a [[Megan's Law]] violation.{{cite news|title=Longtime Etan Patz Suspect Released, Then Held |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/longtime-suspect-etan-patz-case-be-released-0 |first=Michael |last=Rubinkam |work=Associated Press |date=November 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110064444/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/longtime-suspect-etan-patz-case-be-released-0 |archivedate=November 10, 2012 |df=mdy }} Stan and Julie Patz had the 2004 judgment against Ramos dismissed after the 2015 trial of Pedro Hernandez convinced them that Ramos was not responsible for their son's death.{{cite news |url=http://www.ny1.com/nyc/all-boroughs/news/2016/09/12/jury-selection-begins-in-re-trial-of-man-accused-of-killing-etan-patz.html |title=Jury Selection Begins in Re-Trial of Man Accused of Killing Etan Patz |first=Michael |last=Herzenberg |work=NY1 News |date=September 12, 2016}} ==Case reopened== Manhattan District Attorney [[Cyrus Vance, Jr.]] officially reopened the case on May 25, 2010.{{cite news | title = Manhattan D.A. Taking New Look at Etan Patz Case | agency = The Associated Press | work = CBS News | date = May 26, 2010 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/manhattan-da-taking-new-look-at-etan-patz-case/ | accessdate = September 15, 2014}} On April 19, 2012, [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) and [[New York City Police Department]] (NYPD) investigators began [[Wiktionary:excavate#Verb|excavating]] the [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]] basement of 127-B Prince Street, near the Patz home. This residence had been newly refurbished shortly after Etan's disappearance in 1979, and the basement had been the workshop and storage space of a handyman.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/21/nyregion/etan-patz-inquiry-returns-to-a-prince-street-basement-and-an-old-handyman.html |title=Search for Boy's Body Returns to Cellar That Looked Uneven Decades Earlier |last1=Baker |first1=Al |last2=Rashbaum |first2=William K. |date=April 20, 2012 |newspaper=The New York Times |accessdate=April 22, 2012}} After a four-day search, investigators announced that there was "nothing conclusive found."{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/22/etan-patz-search-nothing-conclusive-found_n_1444466.html |title=Etan Patz Search: Investigators Looking For Clues In Boy's 1979 Disappearance Find 'Nothing Conclusive' In New York Basement |last1=Nichols |first1=Michelle |last2=Allen |first2=Jonathan |date=April 22, 2012 |agency=Reuters|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=April 23, 2012}} ===Confession=== On May 24, 2012, New York Police Commissioner [[Raymond Kelly]] announced that a man was in custody who had implicated himself in Etan's disappearance.{{cite news |last=Candiotti |first=Susan |date=May 24, 2012 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/05/24/justice/new-york-etan-patz/ |title=Man in custody in 1979 Etan Patz case|work=[[CNN]]}} According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', a law enforcement official identified the man as 51-year-old Pedro Hernandez of [[Maple Shade Township, New Jersey|Maple Shade, New Jersey]], and said that he had confessed to strangling the child.{{cite news |last1=Rashbaum |first1=William K. |first2=Joseph |last2=Goldstein |date=May 24, 2011 |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/24/man-claims-role-in-disappearance-of-etan-patz-police-say/ |title=Man Confesses to Strangling Etan Patz, Police Say |newspaper=The New York Times}} He stated in his written confession to police, "I’m sorry, I shoke [sic] him."{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2012/05/25/etan-patz-killer-charged-with-second-degree-murder-in-hospital-arraignment/|title=Etan Patz ‘killer’ charged with second-degree murder in hospital arraignment|date=2012-05-25|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-05-25|language=en-US}} According to a 2009 book about the case, ''[[After Etan]]'', Etan had a dollar and had told his parents he planned to buy a soda to drink with his lunch. At the time of Etan's disappearance, Hernandez was an 18-year-old [[convenience store]] worker in a neighborhood [[Convenience store|bodega]].{{cite news |last1=Goldstein |first1=Joseph |last2=Rashbaum |first2=William K. |date=May 24, 2012 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/25/nyregion/man-claims-he-strangled-etan-patz-police-say.html |title=After 33 Years, Police Make Arrest in Case of Etan Patz |newspaper=The New York Times}} Hernandez said that he later threw Etan's remains into the garbage.{{cite news |last1=Celona |first1=Larry |last2=Margolin |first2=Josh |date=May 24, 2012 |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/person_in_custody_in_patz_disappearance_eEcUgDAqlekvwMV0B4QMyJ |title=Person in Custody In Patz Disappearance |newspaper=New York Post}} Hernandez was charged with second-degree murder. According to a ''New York Times'' report from May 25, 2012, the police at that time had no physical evidence to corroborate his confession.{{cite news |last1=Rashbaum |first1=William K. |first2=Gregory |last2=Kia |date=May 25, 2012|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/26/nyregion/suspect-in-etan-patz-case-charged-with-second-degree-murder.html |title=At Arraignment in Etan Patz Case, Mental Illness Claim |newspaper=The New York Times}} ===Corroborating evidence=== In 2012 a man from New Jersey, Jose Lopez, reached out to investigators: He believed that Hernandez, Lopez's brother-in-law, was in fact responsible for Etan's disappearance.{{cite News|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/30/nyregion/what-happened-to-etan-patz.html |title=What Happened to Etan Patz? Unraveling a Nearly 40-Year-Old Case|publisher=The New York Times|author=Rick Rojas |date=January 30, 2017|accessdate=July 16, 2017}} Statements by Hernandez's sister, Nina Hernandez, and Tomas Rivera, leader of a [[Charismatic Christianity]] group at St. Anthony of Padua, a [[Roman Catholic]] church in [[Camden, New Jersey]], indicated that Hernandez may have publicly confessed to murdering Etan in the presence of fellow parishioners in the early 1980s. According to Hernandez's sister, it was an "open family secret that he had confessed in the church."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/28/nyregion/worshiper-recalls-admission-by-patz-suspect-decades-ago.html |title=Worshiper Recalls Admission by Patz Suspect Decades Ago |first1=Michael |last1=Wilson |first2=Kia |last2=Gregory |first3=Nate |last3=Schweber |date=May 27, 2012 |accessdate=May 30, 2012 |newspaper=The New York Times}} A New York [[grand jury]] indicted Hernandez on November 14, 2012, on charges of second-degree murder and first-degree kidnapping.{{cite news |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Etan-Patz-Suspect-Pedro-Hernandez-Grand-Jury-Charges-Indictment-179304281.html |title=Etan Patz Suspect Indicted on Murder, Kidnapping Charges |first1=Jonathan |last1=Dienst|first2=Shimon |last2=Prokupecz|work=[[NBC]] New York |date=November 14, 2012 |accessdate=November 15, 2012}} His lawyer has stated that Hernandez was diagnosed with [[schizotypal personality disorder]], which includes [[hallucination]]s.{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Killer-of-first-milk-carton-boy-formally-charged/tabid/417/articleID/276798/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ| title= Killer of first 'milk carton' boy formally charged| first1 = Jennifer | last1 = Peltz | first2 = Tom | last2 = Hayes | date=November 15, 2012}} The lawyer has also said his client has a low [[intelligence quotient]] (IQ) of around 70, "at the border of intellectual disability." ===Trials and conviction=== On December 12, 2012, Hernandez pleaded not guilty to two counts of murder and one count of kidnapping in a New York court.{{cite news |title=Etan Patz murder suspect pleads not guilty |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/12/justice/new-york-etan-patz-pedro-hernandez/ | first = David | last = Ariosto | date = December 13, 2012 | work=CNN |accessdate=December 12, 2012}} In April 2013, Harvey Fishbein, Hernandez's [[legal aid]] criminal defense lawyer, filed a motion to dismiss the case, citing that Hernandez's "confession in one of the nation's most notorious child disappearances was false, peppered with questionable claims and made after almost seven hours of police questioning".{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/17/pedro-hernandez-etan-patz_n_3105116.html | work= Huffington Post| title= Pedro Hernandez's Lawyer Asks Court To Toss Etan Patz Killing Confession | first = Jennifer | last = Peltz | date=April 17, 2013}} The next month, however, [[New York Supreme Court]] Justice Maxwell Wiley ruled that the evidence was "legally sufficient to support the charges" and that the case could move forward. He also ordered a hearing to determine whether the defendant's statements could be used at trial.{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/15/pedro-hernandez-etan-patz-murder-case-trial_n_3278117.html | work= Huffington Post| title= Pedro Hernandez, Charged With Murder Of Etan Patz, To Face Trial | first = Jennifer | last = Peltz | date=May 15, 2013}} Hernandez had a hearing in September 2014 about whether his statements made prior to police giving him his [[Miranda warning|Miranda rights]] were legally admissible at trial. This would be influenced by whether or not he felt free to leave during the time before he was informed of his Miranda rights. The hearing was also to determine whether or not he understood the significance of the Miranda rights and was competent to waive them when he did so. This was significant because it would decide whether any statements made after that point by Hernandez were legally admissible at trial. The actual truth or falsehood of the statements was not the focus of the hearing;{{cite news | url = http://news.msn.com/crime-justice/confession-is-focus-of-nyc-missing-boy-hearing | title = Confession is focus of NYC missing boy hearing | first = Jennifer | last = Peltz | date = September 14, 2014 | work = MSN News}} rather, the question of the statements' truthfulness was to be discussed in the trial, which began on January 5, 2015.{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2014/05/07/jan-5-trial-date-set-for-man-charged-with-murder-in-case-new-york-boy-missing.html |title=Jan. 5 trial date set for man charged with murder in case of New York boy missing since 1979 |work=Associated Press |date=May 7, 2014 |accessdate=January 31, 2017}} The case resulted in a [[mistrial]] in May 2015 due to a [[hung jury]], which was deadlocked 11 against 1 for [[conviction]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/09/nyregion/etan-patz-jury-murder-trial.html |title=Jurors in Etan Patz Case Fall One Vote Shy of a Conviction |first=James C., Jr. |last=McKinley |newspaper=The New York Times |date=May 8, 2015 |accessdate=May 9, 2015}} A retrial began on October 19, 2016, in a New York City court,{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/trial-no-2-suspected-etan-patz-killer-pedro-hernandez-begins-article-1.2836703 |title=Second trial for suspected Etan Patz killer Pedro Hernandez begins as prosecutor looks back to 1979 NYC |newspaper=New York Daily News |date=October 19, 2016 |accessdate=October 19, 2016}} with jury deliberations in February 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/30/nyregion/what-happened-to-etan-patz.html |title=What Happened to Etan Patz? Unraveling a Nearly 40-Year-Old Case |first=Rick |last=Rojas |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 30, 2017 |accessdate=January 31, 2017}} On February 14, 2017, Hernandez was found guilty of kidnapping and felony murder.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/etan-patz-murder-suspect-pedro-hernandez-found-guilty-killing-article-1.2972203|title=Etan Patz murder suspect Pedro Hernandez found guilty of killing 6-year-old in 1979|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=February 14, 2017|access-date=February 14, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/14/nyregion/etan-patz-pedro-hernandez-guilty.html|title=Pedro Hernandez Found Guilty of Kidnapping and Killing Etan Patz in 1979|newspaper=New York Times|date=February 14, 2017|access-date=February 14, 2017}} Sentencing was scheduled on February 28, with Hernandez facing up to 25 years to life in prison. However, Hernandez's attorneys were granted a delay so as to be able to challenge the verdict, and no new sentencing date was set.{{cite news |title=Sentencing Delayed for Pedro Hernandez, Man Convicted of Killing Etan Patz |author= |url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/02/28/pedro-hernandez-sentencing-delay/ |publisher=[[CBS]] New York |date=February 28, 2017 |accessdate=February 28, 2017}} On April 18, 2017, Hernandez was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole for 25 years. ==Aftermath== In 1983, the May 25 anniversary of Etan Patz's disappearance was designated [[National Missing Children's Day]] in the United States.[http://www.helpbringthemhome.org.au/ "May 25 – International Missing Children's Day"], Help Bring Them Home[http://www.ojjdp.gov/programs/postercontest/ "National Missing Children's Day"], Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention In 2001, the tribute spread worldwide.[http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=13375 "International Missing Childrens Day May 25, 2014"], An Garda Síochána, May 25, 2014{{cite web|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=241279&Cat=5&dt=5/28/2010 |title=Missing Children's Day passes unnoticed |date=May 26, 2010 |work=The News International, Pakistan |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209084614/http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=241279&Cat=5&dt=5%2F28%2F2010 |archivedate=December 9, 2014 |df= }} The [[International Centre for Missing & Exploited Children]] (ICMEC) coordinates the "Help Bring Them Home" campaign in 22 countries in conjunction with International Missing Children's Day.{{cite web|url=http://www.missingpersons.gov.au/awareness/campaigns/youthchildrens-day.aspx |title=Missing Persons: International Missing Children's Day: May 25 |publisher=Australian Federal Police |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141206213340/http://www.missingpersons.gov.au/awareness/campaigns/youthchildrens-day.aspx |archivedate=December 6, 2014 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.newstalk.ie/Today-marks-International-Missing-Childrens-Day|title=Today marks International Missing Children's Day; It is estimated 8 million children are reported missing each year|first=Jack|last=Quann|date=May 25, 2014|work=newstalk}}{{cite web|url=http://www.grreporter.info/en/2012_311_children_went_missing_greece/9354|title=In 2012, 311 children went missing in Greece|publisher=GR Reporter|date=May 25, 2013}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=to5Q_S8t-3A "Missing Children Day May 25, 2011"], YouTube (video), DontYouForgetAboutMe[http://icmec.org/missingkids/servlet/NewsEventServlet?LanguageCountry=en_X1&PageId=5055 " Countries around the world honor International Missing Children's Day on May 25"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214143407/http://icmec.org/missingkids/servlet/NewsEventServlet?LanguageCountry=en_X1&PageId=5055 |date=December 14, 2014 }}, ICMEC The extensive media attention given to Etan's disappearance has been credited with creating greater attention to missing children, resulting in changes such as less willingness to allow children to walk to school, photos of missing children being printed on milk cartons, and promotion of the concept of "[[stranger danger]]", the idea that all adults not known to the child must be regarded as potential sources of danger.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/features/archive/2014/03/hey-parents-leave-those-kids-alone/358631/ |title=The Overprotected Kid |author=Rosin, Hanna |date=March 19, 2014 |magazine=The Atlantic}} ==See also== *[[Crime in New York City]] *[[List of murder convictions without a body]] *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |title=After Etan: The Missing Child Case That Held America Captive |authorlink=Lisa R. Cohen |first=Lisa R. |last=Cohen |publisher=Grand Central Publishing |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-44658251-3}} * [http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-05-11/who-really-killed-etan-patz/ "The Original Milk Carton Kid," ''The Daily Beast''] ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|7281029|Etan Patz}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20150921122702/https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/2015/may/national-missing-childrens-day-2015 Help Us Find Them - National Missing Children's Day 2015] *{{NCMEC|603392|Etan Patz}} {{Portal bar|Criminal justice|New York City|Biography|Death}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Patz, Etan}} [[Category:Missing person cases in New York]] [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:1979 deaths]] [[Category:1979 in New York (state)]] [[Category:1970s missing person cases]] [[Category:20th century in New York City]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]] [[Category:May 1979 events]] [[Category:Missing American children]] [[Category:Murdered American children]] [[Category:Murdered American Jews]] [[Category:Murder convictions without a body]] [[Category:People declared dead in absentia]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:SoHo, Manhattan]]
