'''Pseudodementia''' (otherwise known as “depression-related cognitive dysfunction”) is a condition whose presenting symptoms appear as dementia, but may result from a misdiagnosis of depression or the adverse effects of medications being taken.<ref name="Gale">Thakur, Mugdha Ekanath. "[http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/CX2661000198/GVRL?u=cuny_laguardia&sid=GVRL&xid=3ad1e77f Pseudodementia]." Encyclopedia of Health & Aging, edited by Kyriakos S. Markides, SAGE Reference, 2007, pp. 477-478. Gale Virtual Reference Library. Accessed 5 July 2018. {{subscription required}}</ref> This form of dementia is not the true form and does not result from the same cognitive changes. Once the depression is properly treated or the medication therapy is changed, the cognitive impairment can be effectively reversed. True dementia involves a steady and irreversible cognitive decline. In addition, diminished mental capacity and social withdrawal are commonly identified as symptoms in the elderly but oftentimes is due to symptoms of depression.<ref name="Tabers">Venes, Donald. Taber's Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary.Philadelphia: F.A. Davis Company, [2017] Print.</ref> As a result, elderly patients are often misdiagnosed especially when healthcare professionals do not make an accurate assessment.
Pseudodementia is a phenotype approximated by a wide variety of underlying disorders.<ref>{{cite book|url=|title=Language and Communication in Old Age: Multidisciplinary Perspectives|last=Emery|first=VOB|date=1999|publisher=Garland Pub|year=|isbn=978-0-8153-2356-3|editor-last=Hamilton|editor-first=Heidi|series=Issues in Aging|volume=9|location=New York|pages=25–63|chapter=The relation between memory and language in the dementia spectrum of depression, Alzheimer syndrome, and normal aging|oclc=906769876|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d3LTOkY52NUC&pg=PA25}}</ref> Data indicate that some of the disorders that can convert to a pseudodementia-like presentation include [[depression (mood)]], [[schizophrenia]], [[mania]], [[dissociative disorders]], [[Ganser syndrome]], [[conversion reaction]], and [[psychoactive drugs]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Pseudodementia: A Theoretical and Empirical Discussion|last1=Emery|first1=V. Olga B|last2=Case Western Reserve Geriatric Education Center|date=1988|publisher=Western Reserve Geriatric Education Center|year=|isbn=|series=Interdisciplinary monograph series|volume=4|location=Cleveland, Ohio|pages=}}</ref> Although the frequency distribution of disorders presenting as pseudodementia remains unclear, what is clear is that depressive pseudodementia, synonymously referred to as depressive [[dementia]]<ref>{{cite book|title=Dementia: Presentations, Differential Diagnosis, and Nosology|last1=Emery|first1=V. Olga B.|last2=Oxman|first2=Thomas E.|date=2003|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|year=|isbn=978-0-8018-7156-6|location=|pages=361–397|chapter=A 'prepermanent intermediate-stage dementia' in a long-term disease course of permanent dementia?|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F91VJN-iTsEC&pg=PA361}}</ref> or major depression with depressive dementia, represents a major subclass of the overarching category of pseudodementia.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Emery VOB, Oxman TE|year=1992|title=Update on the dementia spectrum of depression|url=|journal=American Journal of Psychiatry|volume=149|issue=|pages=305–317|doi=10.1176/ajp.149.3.305}}</ref> It has long been observed that in the differential diagnosis between dementia and pseudodementia, depressive pseudodementia appears to be the single most difficult disorder to distinguish from nosologically established "organic" categories of dementia,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Emery|first1=V. O.|last2=Oxman|first2=T. E.|date=1997|title=Depressive dementia: A 'transitional dementia'?|url=|journal=Clinical Neuroscience|volume=4|issue=1|pages=23–30|issn=1065-6766|pmid=9056119|via=}}</ref> especially degenerative dementia of the Alzheimer type.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Emery VOB|year=2011|title=Alzheimer disease: Are we intervening too late?|url=|journal=Journal Neural Transmission|volume=118|issue=|pages=1361–1378|doi=10.1007/s00702-011-0663-0}}</ref> ''Depressive pseudodementia'' is a syndrome seen in older people in which they exhibit symptoms consistent with dementia but the cause is actually [[depression (mood)|depression]].
Older people with predominantly cognitive symptoms such as [[loss of memory]], and vagueness, as well as prominent slowing of movement and reduced or slowed speech, were sometimes misdiagnosed as having dementia when further investigation showed they were suffering from a [[major depressive episode]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Caine |first=ED |year=1981 |title= Pseudodementia. Current concepts and future directions |journal=Archives of General Psychiatry |volume=38 |issue=12 |pages=1359–64 |pmid=7316680 |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.1981.01780370061008}}</ref> This was an important distinction as the former was untreatable and progressive and the latter treatable with [[antidepressant]] therapy, [[electroconvulsive therapy]], or both.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 3955324 | year = 1986 | title = Pseudodementia: Facts and figures | volume = 148 |issue=1| pages = 87–94 | journal = The British Journal of Psychiatry |vauthors=Bulbena A, Berrios GE| doi=10.1192/bjp.148.1.87}}</ref> In contrast to major depression, dementia is a progressive [[neurodegenerative]] syndrome involving a pervasive impairment of higher cortical functions resulting from widespread brain pathology.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Warrell|first1=David|last2=Timothy|first2=Cox|last3=John|first3=Firth|title=Neuropsychiatric disorders|doi=10.1093/med/9780199204854.003.2604|url=http://oxfordmedicine.com/view/10.1093/med/9780199204854.001.1/med-9780199204854-chapter-2604}}</ref>
== Treatments == If effective medical treatment for depression is given, this can aid in the distinction between pseudodementia and dementia. Antidepressants have been found to assist in the elimination of cognitive dysfunction associated with depression, whereas cognitive dysfunction associated with true dementia continues along a steady gradient. In cases where antidepressant therapy is not well tolerated, patients can consider electroconvulsive therapy as a possible alternative. <ref name="Gale"/> However, studies have revealed that patients who displayed cognitive dysfunction related to depression eventually developed dementia later on in their lives.
The development of treatments for dementia has not been as fast as those for depression. Thus far, cholinesterase inhibitors is the most popular drug used to combat dementia and provides improvement in cognitive function.<ref name="Gale2">Swartout-Corbeil, Deanna M., and Rebecca J. Frey. "[http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/CX2760400298/GVRL?u=cuny_laguardia&sid=GVRL&xid=9b8469b6 Dementia]." The Gale Encyclopedia of Nursing and Allied Health, edited by Brigham Narins, 3rd ed., vol. 2, Gale, 2013, pp. 966-976. Gale Virtual Reference Library. Accessed 20 Aug. 2018. {{subscription required}}</ref>
==History and controversy of term== The term was first coined in 1961 by psychiatrist [[Leslie Gordon Kiloh|Leslie Kiloh]], who noticed patients with cognitive symptoms consistent with dementia who improved with treatment. Reversible causes of true dementia must be excluded.<ref name=":0" /> His term was mainly descriptive.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kiloh |first=Leslie Gordon |authorlink=Leslie Gordon Kiloh |year=1961 |title=Pseudodementia |journal= [[Acta Psychiatr Scand]] |volume=37 |pages=336–51 |pmid=14455934 | doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0447.1961.tb07367.x }}</ref> The clinical phenomenon, however, was well-known since the late 19th century as melancholic dementia.<ref name=pmid3889224>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/jnnp.48.5.393 |author=Berrios GE |title="Depressive pseudodementia" or "Melancholic dementia": a 19th century view |journal=J. Neurol. Neurosurg. Psychiatry |volume=48 |issue=5 |pages=393–400 |date=May 1985 |pmid=3889224 |pmc=1028324 |url=http://jnnp.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=3889224}}</ref>
Doubts about the classification and features of the syndrome,<ref>{{cite journal |last=McAllister |first=TW |date=May 1983 |title=Overview: Pseudodementia |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=140 |issue=5 |pages=528–33 |pmid=6342420|doi=10.1176/ajp.140.5.528}}</ref> and the misleading nature of the name, led to proposals that the term be dropped.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Poon |first=Leonard W |year=1991 |title=Toward an understanding of cognitive functioning in geriatric depression |journal=International Psychogeriatrics |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=241–66 |doi=10.1017/S1041610292001297 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=272114 }}</ref> However, proponents argue that although it is not a defined singular concept with a precise set of symptoms, it is a practical and useful term which has held up well in clinical practice, and also highlights those who may have a treatable condition.<ref>{{cite book |title=Dementia: Presentations, Differential Diagnosis, and Nosology |editor1=V. Olga B. Emery |editor2=Thomas E. Oxman |author1=Sachdev, Perminder |author2=Reutens, Sharon |chapter=The Nondepressive Pseudodementias |year=2003 |publisher=JHU Press |isbn=0-8018-7156-5 |page=418}}</ref>
==Presentation and differential== The history of disturbance in pseudodementia is often short and abrupt onset, while dementia is more often insidious. Clinically, people with pseudodementia differ from those with true dementia when their memory is tested. They will often answer that they don't know the answer to a question, and their attention and concentration are often intact, and they may appear upset or distressed. Those with true dementia will often give wrong answers, have poor attention and concentration, and appear indifferent or unconcerned.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wells |first=CE |date=May 1979 |title=Pseudodementia |journal=American Journal of Psychiatry |volume=136 |issue=7 |pages=895–900 |pmid=453349 |doi=10.1176/ajp.136.7.895}}</ref>
The implementation and application of existing collaborative care models such as DICE can aid in avoiding misdiagnosis. Comorbidities (such as vascular, infectious, traumatic, autoimmune, idiopathic, or even malnourishment) have the potential to mimic symptoms of dementia.<ref name="Kverno">Kverno, Karan S. and Roseann Velez. “Comorbid Dementia and Depression: The Case for Integrated Care.” Journal for Nurse Practitioners Volume 14, Issue 3, March 2018, Pages 196-201. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nurpra.2017.12.032</ref> For instance, studies have also shown a relationship between depression and its cognitive effects on everyday functioning and distortions of memory. <ref name="memory">Sjunaite, Karolina, Claudia Lanza, and Matthias W. Riepe. “Everyday false memories in older persons with depressive disorder.” Psychiatry Research 261 (2018): 456-463. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.psychres.2018.01.030</ref>
Investigations such as [[Positron emission tomography|PET]] and [[SPECT]] imaging of the brain show reduced blood flow in areas of the brain in people with [[Alzheimer's disease]], compared with a more normal blood flow in those with pseudodementia.<ref>{{cite book |title=Melancholia: A disorder of movement and mood: A phenomenological and neurobiological review |last=Parker |first=Gordon |authorlink= Gordon Parker (psychiatrist) |author2=Dusan Hadzi-Pavlovic |author3=Kerrie Eyers |year=1996 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |isbn=0-521-47275-X |pages=273–74}}</ref>

[[File:Hinrichtung Ludwig des XVI.png|right|thumb|250px|Execution of [[Louis XVI of France]], copperplate engraving, 1793]]
A '''public execution''' is a form of [[capital punishment]] which "members of the general public may voluntarily attend."<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/capital-punishment |title=Capital punishment |first=Roger |last=Hood |access-date=3 October 2018 |journal=[[Encyclopedia Britannica]] |publisher=[[Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc.]]}}</ref> This definition excludes the presence of a small number of witnesses randomly selected to assure executive accountability.<ref name=blum>{{cite journal |last=Blum |first=Steven A. |date=Winter 1992 |title=Public Executions: Understand the "Cruel and Unusual Punishments" Clause |url=http://www.hastingsconlawquarterly.org/archives/V19/I2/Blum.pdf |journal=Hastings Constitutional Law Quarterly |publisher= |volume=19 |issue=2 |page=415 |doi= |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140326225628/http://www.hastingsconlawquarterly.org/archives/V19/I2/Blum.pdf |archivedate=2014-03-26 |df= }}</ref>
While today most countries regard public executions with distaste, in the past they were preferred to executions behind closed doors because they allowed the convicted the opportunity to make a final speech, gave the state the chance to display its power in front of those who fell under its jurisdiction, and granted the public what was considered to be a great spectacle.<ref name=Cawthorne>{{cite book |last=Cawthorne |first=Nigel |date=2006 |title=Public Executions: From Ancient Rome to the Present Day |url= |location= |publisher= |pages=6–7 |isbn=978-0-7858-2119-9 }}</ref> Public executions also permitted the state to project its superiority over political opponents.<ref name=Cawthorne/> Thus, when [[Charles I of England]] was beheaded, the reduced height of the block meant that he could not assume the normal kneeling pose, but was forced to lie in a face-down position considered to be especially humiliating.<ref name=Cawthorne/>
In Europe and in the northern U.S., the 19th and early 20th centuries saw a shift away from the spectacle of public capital punishment and toward administration of punishment via the deprivation of liberty.<ref name=chambliss>{{cite book|author=William J. Chambliss|title=Corrections|publisher=SAGE Publications|year=2011|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NMF1AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA4|pages=4–5}}</ref> While some reformers opposed capital punishment, public executions remained common throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries.<ref name=chambliss/> Social historians note that beginning in the 20th century in the U.S. and western Europe death in general became increasingly shielded from public view, occurring more and more behind the closed doors of the hospital.<ref name=chambliss/> Executions were likewise moved behind the walls of the penitentiary.<ref name=chambliss/> The last formal public executions occurred in 1868 in Britain, in 1936 in the U.S. and in 1939 in France.<ref name=chambliss/>
According to [[Amnesty International]], in 2012 "public executions were known to have been carried out in [[Public executions in Iran|Iran]], [[Public executions in North Korea|North Korea]], [[Capital punishment in Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabia]] and [[Somalia]]."<ref>{{cite news |last=Rogers |first=Simon |last2=Chalabi |first2=Mona |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2011/mar/29/death-penalty-countries-world |title=Death penalty statistics, country by country |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2013-12-13 |accessdate=2015-12-13 }}</ref> [[Amnesty International]] does not include Syria, Afghanistan, and Yemen in their list of public execution countries, but there have been reports of public executions carried out there by state and non-state actors, such as [[ISIS]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/01/08/isis-extremist-executes-his-mother-in-syria-for-urging-him-to-flee-group.html |title=ISIS extremist reportedly kills his mother in public execution in Syria |publisher=Fox News |date=2016-01-08 |accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2014/08/08/world/isis-fast-facts/index.html |title=ISIS Fast Facts |author=CNN Library |date=3 September 2018 |access-date=9 October 2018 |work=[[Cable News Network]] |publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System, Inc.]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Cohen |first=Tamara |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1197900/Justice-Yemen-style-Paedophile-raped-boy-11-shot-head-hundreds-spectators.html |title=Justice Yemen-style: Paedophile who raped boy, 11, shot in the head in front of hundreds of spectators | Daily Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2009-07-07 |accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Updated 6:21 AM ET, Mon July 9, 2012 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/08/world/asia/afghanistan-public-execution/ |title=Video: Taliban shoot woman 9 times in public execution as men cheer |publisher=CNN |date=2012-07-09 |accessdate=2016-05-30}}</ref> Executions which can be classified as public were also carried out in the U.S. states of Florida and Utah as of 1992.<ref name=blum/>
==See also== * [[Public executions in Iran]] * [[Public executions in Saudi Arabia]] * [[Public executions in North Korea]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2014}} '''Major Rawshan Yazdani Bhuiyan''' (died 1981) was a [[Bangladesh]]i freedom fighter. He was accused by [[Government of Bangladesh]] for taking part in the [[Assassination of Ziaur Rahman|assassination of president Ziaur Rahman]], and was hanged in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=106746|title=Death anniversary of 13 executed army officers observed|work=The Daily Star|accessdate=9 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/old/2009/09/24/79599.html|title=Families observe death anniversary|work=The Financial Express|accessdate=9 July 2015}}</ref>
==Education== Rowshan was graduated from [[Faujdarhat Cadet College]]. He wanted to be involved into farming, and so after graduation from the Faujdarhat Cadet College when most of his classmates went to military or engineering, he went to [[Bangladesh Agricultural University]], [[Mymensingh]].
== Liberation war == However, during the [[Bangladesh liberation war]] in 1971, he joined the liberation war and after independence, Rowshan was given a commission in the Bangladesh Army. As he had joined the army much later, he was still a Major when his college classmates were already Colonels or Brigadiers in the army.
== Role in assassination of Ziaur Rahman == {{Main|Assassination of Ziaur Rahman}} Rowshan’s role in the assassination is unclear. He was not one of the members of the group who had gone to the Circuit House that night.
However, Rowshan was arrested in the remote Chittagong village, while he was with [[Abul Manzoor|General Manzoor's]] wife and family, trying to find a secure place for them. By that time, with General Manzoor's had already being killed. According to Rowshan’s close friends, “when others had conveniently left Manzoor and joined hands with then CAS [[Hussain Muhammad Ershad]], Rowshan took it up on his shoulder the responsibility of saving the family of the fallen General.”
==Death== Rowshan was found guilty by Military Tribunal.
Rowshan's closest friend in Cadet College was Brigadier General Ashraf who was then Chief of NSI and was personal secretary to the then CAS [[Hussain Muhammad Ershad]]. Rowshan's another close friend Amin (CSP) was PS to the President [[Ziaur Rahman]] and was present during the killing in the same Chittagong Circuit House.
As Rowshan’s last wish, the jail authorities allowed him to send a short telegram to the person he possibly still considered his closest friend. Rowshan send a telegram to Brigadier General Ashraf which said "Save Life". Brigadier General Ashraf did confirm receiving the telegram.
Brigadier General Ashraf also confirmed that till the last moment Yazdani was fighting and tried to climb the well with his tied up legs thus prolonging his death and suffering.

'''Rheoencephalography''' ('''REG''') a technique<ref>Lifshitz, Kenneth M.D., Rheoencephalography: I. Review of the Technique, Journal of Nervous & Mental Disease, April 1963, Volume 136, Issue 4, ppg 388-398</ref> of continuous registration of [[cerebral blood flow]]. An electronic device called a [[rheoencephalograph]] is used in '''rheoencephalography'''.<ref>Jenkner, F. L. Reoentsefalografiia. Moscow, 1966.</ref> Electrodes are attached to the cranium at specific points on the head and allow the device to continuously measure the electrical conductivity of the tissue located between the electrodes. A rheoencephalograph is also used for brain blood flow [[biofeedback]].<ref>Tokarev V.E. "The Use of REG Biofeedback in Occupational Medicine", 26th Annual Meeting of Association of Applied Psychophysiology and Biofeedback, Cincinnati, US, 1995</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120322231152/http://www.rheography.com/ Brain Blood Flow Biofeedback] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110719181855/http://webideas.com/biofeedback/research/vtokarev.shtml The Use of Brain Blood Flow Biofeedback in Occupational Medicine.] [[Category:Neurotechnology]]

{{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} '''Robert Boyd''' (1808–1883),<ref name="ODNB">Nick Hervey, 'Boyd, Robert (1808–1883)', [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]], Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/3114 accessed 4 March 2011]</ref> was a physician and writer on mental illness, who, in 1870 became president of the [[Medico-Psychological Association]]<ref name="ODNB"/> (now the [[Royal College of Psychiatrists]]).
==Life== Boyd became a member of the [[Royal College of Surgeons]] in 1830, and in the following year graduated M.D. in the [[University of Edinburgh]]. In 1836 he became a licentiate of the [[Royal College of Physicians]], and in 1852 was elected to the fellowship of the college. For some time he was resident physician at the Marylebone workhouse infirmary, and afterwards physician and superintendent of the [[Somerset]] county lunatic asylum. He then became proprietor and manager of the Southall Park private asylum, which was destroyed in August 1883 by a fire; he lost his life after re-entering the burning building to rescue thepatients.<ref name="ODNB"/>
In the various positions in which he was placed he utilised to the utmost his opportunities for original research. He was also a Fellow of the [[Zoological Society of London|Zoological Society]] and also an antiquarian.<ref name="ODNB"/>
==Writings== He published the annual ''Reports on the Pauper Lunatics'' at the St. Marylebone infirmary and the Somerset county asylum, and contributed numerous independent papers to the literature of [[pathology]] and psychological medicine. He was the author of pathological contributions to the ''Royal Medical and Chirurgical Transactions'', vols. xxiv. and xxxii., and to the ''Edinburgh Medical Journal'', vols. lv. to lxxii.; of ''Tables of the Weights of the Human Body and Internal Organs'', in the ''[[Philosophical Transactions]]''; and of a paper, ''The Weight of the Brain at different Ages and in various Diseases''.
He contributed no fewer than sixteen papers to the ''Journal of Mental Science'' on "Treatment of the Insane Poor", "Diseases of the Nervous System", "Statistics of Pauper Insanity", and cognate subjects, the most important being that on "[[General paresis of the insane|General Paralysis of the Insane]]" in the ''Journal of Mental Science'' for May and October 1871, the result of 155 [[post-mortem]] examinations of persons who had died from that disease in the Somerset county asylum. He was also the author of three papers on "[[vital signs|vital statistics]]", "[[Insanity]]", and "The Pauper Lunacy Laws", published in ''[[The Lancet]]''.

'''''Empire Engineer''''' was a {{GRT|5,358}} [[reefer ship|refrigerated cargo ship]] that was built in 1921 as '''''Canadian Commander''''' by [[Canadian Vickers|Canadian Vickers Ltd]], [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada. She was sold to an Italian firm in 1932 and renamed '''''Giaocchino Lauro'''''. She was seized by the United Kingdom in 1940, passed to the [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT) and renamed ''Empire Engineer''. She served until 4 February 1941 when she was [[torpedo]]ed and sunk by {{GS|U-123|1940|2}}.
==Description== The SS Empire Engineer was built in 1920 by [[Canadian Vickers|Canadian Vickers Ltd]], [[Montreal]].<ref name=Times231120>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Canada's Trading Fleet |day_of_week=Tuesday |date=23 November 1920 |page_number=7 |issue=42575 |column=B }}</ref> She was yard number 79.<ref name=SBH>{{cite web |url=http://shipbuildinghistory.com/history/canada/shipsbytype/wwone.htm |title=Merchant Ships Built in Canada in World War One |publisher=Ship Building History |accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref>
The ship was {{convert|400|ft|0|in|m|2}} long, with a beam of {{convert|52|ft|4|in|m|2}}. She had a depth of {{convert|28|ft|5|in|m|2}}, and a draught of {{convert|25|ft|4|in|m|2}}.<ref name=Commander30a>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0205.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> She was assessed at {{GRT|6,570}}, {{NRT|4,005}}.<ref name=Grete30>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30b0482.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, STEAMERS & MOTORSHIPS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref> 8,400 [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]].<ref name=Times231120/>
The ship was propelled by a 520 [[nominal horsepower|nhp]] [[triple expansion steam engine]], which had cylinders of {{convert|27|in|cm}}, {{convert|44|in|cm}} and {{convert|73|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|48|in|cm}} stroke. The engine was built by Canadian Vickers Ltd, Montreal.<ref name=Commander30a/><!--It could propel the ship at {{convert|xx|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=xxxx/>--><!-- She was assessed as Ice Class .-->She had {{convert|10325|cuft|m3}} of refrigerated cargo space. Refrigeration machinery was by the Lightfoot Refrigeration Co Ltd<!-- using Carb. Anhydr. (WHAT IS THIS?) as the refrigerant with [[brine]] and granulated [[cork (material)|cork]] for insulation-->.<ref name=Commander30b>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=30a0598.pdf |title=LIST OF VESSELS FITTED WITH REFRIGERATING APPARATUS – continued. Part I. – List of vessels having a capacity of 80,000 cubic feet and over, and including all vessels holding Lloyd's R.M.C. |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref>
==History== ''Canadian Commander'' was launched in 1920,<ref name=Times231120/> with completion in April 1921.<ref name=Commander30a/> She was built for the Canadian Government and operated by the Canadian Government Merchant Marine Ltd (GCMM).<ref name=List/> Her port of registry was Montreal, under the [[Flag of the United Kingdom|British flag]]. The United Kingdom Official Number 141832 and [[Code Letters]] TQDW were allocated.<ref name=Commander30a/> On 3 July 1922, ''Canadian Commander'' ran aground at [[Saint Pierre and Miquelon]]. She was refloated on 16 July.<ref name=Times170722>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Reinsurance Rates |day_of_week=Monday |date=17 July 1922 |page_number=20 |issue=43085 |column=B }}</ref> Following the demise of CGMM in 1928,<ref name=List>{{cite web |url=http://www.theshipslist.com/ships/lines/cgmm.htm |title=Canadian Government Merchant Marine CGMM, Montreal 1918-1928 |publisher=The Ships List |accessdate=1 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308113014/http://www.theshipslist.com/ships/lines/cgmm.htm |archivedate=8 March 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ''Canadian Commander'' was transferred to Canadian Commander Ltd and placed under the management of [[Canadian National Steamships|Canadian National Steamships Ltd]].<ref name=Commander30a/>
In 1932, ''Canadian Commander'' was sold to Achille Lauro, [[Naples]], Italy and renamed ''Gioacchino Lauro''.<ref name=Ships>{{cite book |last1= Mitchell |first1=W.H. |last2=Sawyer |first2=L.A. |year=1995 |title=The Empire Ships |page=not cited |publisher= Lloyd's of London Press Ltd |location= London, New York, Hamburg, Hong Kong |isbn=1-85044-275-4}}</ref> Her port of registry was Naples. The Italian Official Number 383 was allocated. From 1934, her Code Letters were IBOG. She was assessed as {{GRT|5345|link=off}}, {{NRT|3,151|link=off}}.<ref name=Lauro37>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=37b0337.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref> On 10 June 1940, ''Gioacchino Lauro'' was in port at [[Hartlepool]], [[Co Durham]] when [[Military history of Italy during World War II#Italy enters the war: June 1940|Italy declared war]] against the United Kingdom.<ref name=Ships/> The ship and her cargo were seized as a [[prize of war]],<ref name=Times190640>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Prize Courts |day_of_week=Wednesday |date=19 June 1940 |page_number=1 |issue=48646 |column=E }}</ref> ''Gioacchino Lauro'' was passed to the MoWT and renamed ''Empire Engineer''.<ref name=Ships/>
''Empire Engineer'' was placed under the management of Weidner, Hopkins & Co Ltd. She regained her previous Official Number. The Code Letters GLYG were allocated. Her port of registry was [[West Hartlepool]], Co Durham. She was assessed at {{GRT|5358|link=off}}, {{NRT|3,230|link=off}}.<ref name=Engineer40>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=40a1056.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=1 September 2011}}</ref>
Little is known of her war service. She was a member of Convoy OA 216, which departed from [[Methil]], [[Fife]] on 18 September 1940 and joined Convoy OB 216 at sea on 21 September. ''Empire Engineer'' was in ballast and bound for [[Baltimore, Maryland]].<ref name=OA216>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/ob/index.html?oa216.htm~obmain |title=Convoy OA.216 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> ''Empire Engineer'' was a member of Convoy SC 20, which departed from [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]], Canada on 22 January 1941 and arrived at [[Liverpool]], [[Lancashire]], United Kingdom on 8 February. She was carrying a cargo of [[steel]] ingots bound for [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[Monmouthshire (historic)|Monmouthshire]].<ref name=SC20>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/sc20.html |title=CONVOY SC 20 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref> ''Empire Engineer'' straggled behind the convoy. At 16:44 German time on 4 February, she was hit by a torpedo fired by {{GS|U-123|1940|2}} and sank within four minutes at {{coord|54|21|N|23|15|W|display=inline, title}}. Although some survivors were seen to have taken to [[liferaft]]s, all 39 crew were lost.<ref name=Uboat>{{cite web |url=http://www.uboat.net/allies/merchants/754.html |title=Empire Engineer |publisher=Uboat |accessdate=24 February 2012}}</ref> They are commemorated on the [[Tower Hill Memorial]], [[London]].<ref name=Benjidog>{{cite web |url=http://www.benjidog.co.uk/Tower%20Hill/Empire%20Day%20to%20Empire%20Engineer.html |title=Empire Day to Empire Engineer |publisher=Brian Watson |accessdate=2 September 2011}}</ref>

'''Selective reduction''' is the practice of reducing the number of [[fetus]]es in a [[multiple pregnancy]], say [[quadruplets]], to a [[twin]] or singleton pregnancy. The procedure is also called '''multifetal reduction'''.<ref name=ACOG2017>{{cite web |title=Opinion Number 719: Multifetal Pregnancy Reduction |url=https://www.acog.org/Clinical-Guidance-and-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Ethics/Multifetal-Pregnancy-Reduction |publisher=American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists’ Committee on Ethics. |date=September 2017}}</ref> The procedure is most commonly done to reduce the number of fetuses in a multiple pregnancy to a safe number, when the multiple pregnancy is the result of use of [[assisted reproductive technology]]; outcomes for both the mother and the babies are generally worse, the higher the number of fetuses.<ref name=Legendre2013>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.rbmo.2013.02.004 |pmid=23518032 |title=Differences between selective termination of pregnancy and fetal reduction in multiple pregnancy: A narrative review |journal=Reproductive BioMedicine Online |volume=26 |issue=6 |pages=542–54 |year=2013 |last1=Legendre |first1=Claire-Marie |last2=Moutel |first2=Grégoire |last3=Drouin |first3=Régen |last4=Favre |first4=Romain |last5=Bouffard |first5=Chantal }} {{open access}}</ref> The procedure is also used in multiple pregnancies when one of the fetuses has a serious and incurable disease, or in the case where one of the fetuses is [[ectopic pregnancy|outside the uterus]], in which case it is called '''selective termination'''.<ref name=Legendre2013/>
The procedure generally takes two days; the first day for testing in order to select which fetuses to reduce, and the second day for the procedure itself, in which [[potassium chloride]] is injected into the heart of each selected fetus under the guidance of ultrasound imaging.<ref name=Evans2014>{{cite journal |last1=Evans |first1=MI |last2=Andriole |first2=S |last3=Britt |first3=DW |title=Fetal reduction: 25 years' experience. |journal=Fetal Diagnosis and Therapy |date=2014 |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=69–82 |doi=10.1159/000357974 |pmid=24525884}} {{open access}}</ref> Risks of the procedure include bleeding requiring transfusion, rupture of the uterus, [[retained placenta]], infection, a miscarriage, and [[prelabor rupture of membranes]]. Each of these appears to be rare.<ref name=Legendre2013/>
Selective reduction was developed in the mid-1980s, as people in the field of assisted reproductive technology became aware of the risks that multiple pregnancies carried for the mother and for the fetuses.<ref name=WaPO>{{cite news |last1=Mundy |first1=Liza |title=Too Much to Carry? |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/15/AR2007051501730_pf.html |work=Washington Post Magazine |date=May 20, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405010648/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/15/AR2007051501730_pf.html |archivedate=April 5, 2015}}</ref><ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=The Two-Minus-One Pregnancy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/14/magazine/the-two-minus-one-pregnancy.html|publisher=New York Times Magazine|first=Ruth|last=Padawer|date=August 10, 2011}}</ref>
==Medical use== Selective reduction is used when a mother is carrying an unsafe or undesirable number of fetuses in a [[multiple pregnancy]], which are common in [[assisted reproductive technology|medically-assisted pregnancies]], in order to reduce the number of fetuses to a number that is relatively safe for the mother and the remaining fetuses.<ref name=ACOG2017/><ref name=Zipori2017>{{cite journal |last1=Zipori |first1=Y |last2=Haas |first2=J |last3=Berger |first3=H |last4=Barzilay |first4=E |title=Multifetal pregnancy reduction of triplets to twins compared with non-reduced triplets: a meta-analysis. |journal=Reproductive Biomedicine Online |date=September 2017 |volume=35 |issue=3 |pages=296–304 |doi=10.1016/j.rbmo.2017.05.012 |pmid=28625760}} {{open access}}</ref><ref name=Evans2014/> It is also used in cases of multiple pregnancy where at least one of the fetuses is [[ectopic pregnancy|implanted outside the uterus]] to preserve the life of the mother and the fetus in the uterus,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Yeh |first1=J |last2=Aziz |first2=N |last3=Chueh |first3=J |title=Nonsurgical management of heterotopic abdominal pregnancy. |journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology |date=February 2013 |volume=121 |issue=2 Pt 2 Suppl 1 |pages=489–95 |doi=10.1097/AOG.0b013e3182736b09 |pmid=23344419|doi-broken-date=2018-11-04 }}</ref> and when one or more of the fetuses has a serious and incurable disease.<ref name=Legendre2013/>
While the data is weak, due to the small sizes of studies and the lack of randomized controlled trials, as of 2017 it appeared that when short term perinatal outcomes in multiple pregnancies reduced to twins are compared to those of non-reduced triplets, there were fewer deaths among the reduced babies, the twins were born later and were less likely to be [[Preterm birth|premature]], and had higher birthweight.<ref name=Zipori2017/> As of 2017 longterm outcomes were not well understood.<ref name=Zipori2017/> A 2015 Cochrane review found no randomized clinical trials to evaluate.<ref name=Cochrane2015>{{cite journal|last1=Dodd|first1=JM|last2=Dowswell|first2=T|last3=Crowther|first3=CA|title=Reduction of the number of fetuses for women with a multiple pregnancy.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=4 November 2015|volume=11|issue=11|pages=CD003932|pmid=26544079|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD003932.pub3}} {{open access}}</ref>
Generally selective reduction reduces the risk of preterm birth, leading to better outcomes for both mothers and the newborns.<ref name=Obican2015>{{cite journal |last1=Običan |first1=S |last2=Brock |first2=C |last3=Berkowitz |first3=R |last4=Wapner |first4=RJ |title=Multifetal Pregnancy Reduction. |journal=Clinical Obstetrics and Gynecology |date=September 2015 |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=574–84 |doi=10.1097/GRF.0000000000000119 |pmid=26083128}}</ref>
===Outcomes=== Generally selective reduction reduces the risk of preterm birth, leading to better outcomes for both mothers and the newborns.<ref name=Obican2015/>
It appears that reduction of triplets, where each triplet is in its own placenta, to twins results in a lower risk of preterm birth and does not increase the risk of miscarriage. In triplets where two of the fetuses share a placenta and each has its own amniotic sac, it appears, with less certainty, that there is also a lower risk of preterm birth and no increase in the risk of miscarriage.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Anthoulakis |first1=C |last2=Dagklis |first2=T |last3=Mamopoulos |first3=A |last4=Athanasiadis |first4=A |title=Risks of miscarriage or preterm delivery in trichorionic and dichorionic triplet pregnancies with embryo reduction versus expectant management: a systematic review and meta-analysis. |journal=Human Reproduction (Oxford, England) |date=1 June 2017 |volume=32 |issue=6 |pages=1351–1359 |doi=10.1093/humrep/dex084 |pmid=28444191}}</ref>
==Adverse effects== Risks of the procedure include bleeding requiring transfusion, rupture of the uterus, [[retained placenta]], infection, a miscarriage, and [[prelabor rupture of membranes]]. Each of these appears to be rare.<ref name=Legendre2013/>
==Procedure== The reduction procedure is generally carried out during the first trimester of pregnancy. The procedure often takes two days; the first day is for testing, and the procedure happens on the second day. The fetuses are evaluated, first by [[Abdominal ultrasonography|ultrasound]], then often by [[amniocentesis|testing the amniotic fluid]] and [[chorionic villus sampling]]; these tests help determine which fetuses are accessible for the procedure, and whether any fetuses are unhealthy. Once the specific fetuses to be reduced are identified, [[potassium chloride]] is injected into the heart of each selected fetus under the guidance of ultrasound imaging; the heart stops and the fetus dies as a result. Generally, the fetal material is reabsorbed into the woman's body.<ref name=Evans2014/>
==History== Selective reduction was developed in the mid-1980s, as people in the field of [[assisted reproductive technology]] became aware of the risks that multiple pregnancies carried for the mother and for the fetuses.<ref name=WaPO/><ref name=NYT/> The procedure was somewhat controversial from the beginning, and drew some attention from anti-abortion activists.<ref name=NYT/>
A set of ethical guidelines was developed in collaboration with a bioethicist from NIH and was published in 1988; it justified reducing pregnancies with more than three fetuses to two or three.<ref name=NYT/><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Evans |first1=MI |last2=Fletcher |first2=JC |last3=Zador |first3=IE |last4=Newton |first4=BW |last5=Quigg |first5=MH |last6=Struyk |first6=CD |title=Selective first-trimester termination in octuplet and quadruplet pregnancies: clinical and ethical issues. |journal=Obstetrics and Gynecology |date=March 1988 |volume=71 |issue=3 Pt 1 |pages=289–96 |pmid=3347412 |url=https://journals.lww.com/greenjournal/Abstract/1988/03000/Selective_First_Trimester_Termination_in_Octuplet.1.aspx}} {{open access}}</ref>
Over time, more and more women sought to become pregnant when they were older, having the first child when they were over forty years old. At the same time, the field of ART matured, and massively multiple pregnancies became more rare. Both trends led to more women asking for reduction to one fetus, which was very controversial at first, but has gradually become more accepted. [[Sex-selective abortion|Sex-selective reduction]] is widely considered to be unethical in making decisions about which fetus to keep.<ref name=ACOG2017/><ref name=Evans2014/><ref name=NYT/>

'''Slim Smith''' (born Keith Smith; 1948 in [[Kingston, Jamaica]] – 1973) was a [[ska]], [[rocksteady]] and [[reggae]] singer. In their book ''Reggae: The Rough Guide'' (1997), Steve Barrow and Peter Dalton described Smith as "the greatest vocalist to emerge in the rocksteady era".<ref name="Barrow">Barrow, Steve & Dalton, Peter: "Reggae: The Rough Guide", 1997, Rough Guides, {{ISBN|1-85828-247-0}}</ref>
==Biography== Smith first came to prominence as a member of the Victors Youth Band, who were highly praised at the 1964 Jamaican Festival.<ref name="Larkin">{{cite book | last=Larkin | first=Colin | title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Reggae| year=1998 | publisher=Virgin Books | isbn=0-7535-0242-9}}</ref> He subsequently became a founding member and lead vocalist of [[The Techniques]], who recorded primarily with [[Duke Reid]] for his Treasure Isle label. In 1964 they recorded several songs for [[Byron Lee]], two of which, "Don't Do It" and "No One", were included on the LP ''The Real Jamaica Ska'' released by Epic Records and co-produced by [[Curtis Mayfield]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Bradley | first=Lloyd | title=This Is Reggae Music:The Story Of Jamaica's Music | publisher=Grove Press | year=2001 | page=138}}</ref> After the Techniques disbanded in 1965, he formed [[The Uniques (Jamaican group)|The Uniques]], who released a handful of singles including the R&B influenced "Do Me Good" released on [[Ken Lack]]'s Caltone records in 1966.<ref>Pete Holdsworth, Article on Caltone's Jamaican 45's 1966-69, published with CD, Pressure Sounds, 2012</ref>
In 1969 Slim Smith commenced recording for [[Prince Buster]] and [[Coxsone Dodd]]'s [[Studio One (record label)|Studio One]] label, the main rival to Duke Reid. His Studio One recordings brilliantly highlight his passionate, soulful voice, which had an almost manic edge, and confirm him as one of Jamaica's greatest singers. His hits from this period include "The New Boss", "Hip Hug" and "Rougher Yet", many of which were later compiled for the album ''Born To Love''. In 1967 he formed a new version of The Uniques, and commenced his association with producer [[Bunny Lee]]. They topped the Jamaican hit parade with "Let Me Go Girl", but after recording one album, ''Absolutely The Uniques'', Smith left the group, staying with Lee to concentrate on a solo career.
He had a hit almost immediately with "Everybody Needs Love". An album of the same name quickly followed, as did many further hits. By 1972 personal problems led to him being detained at Bellevue sanatorium.<ref name="Observer1">"[http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/entertainment/Slim-Smith--the-influential-singer_12307436 Slim Smith, the influential singer: Unsung]", ''[[Jamaica Observer]]'', 17 August 2012, retrieved 1 September 2012</ref>
Smith died in 1973. Unable to gain entry to his parents' house, he broke a window, badly lacerating his arm. He bled to death before he could receive treatment.<ref>[http://www.pressure.co.uk/item/PS21/ The Pressure Sounds Website | The Uniques — Watch This Sound]</ref> His death stunned Jamaica. Still widely regarded as one of Jamaica's great vocalists, his enduring popularity has resulted in the reissue of the bulk of his work.
==Album discography== *''Everybody Needs Love'' (1969, [[Pama Records|Pama]]) *''Just a Dream'' (1972, Pama/Trojan) *''Memorial'' (1973, Trojan) *''Dancehall Connection'' (1986, Third World) *''Born To Love'' (198?, Studio One) *''Early Days'' (19??, Striker Lee) *''Rain From The Skies'' (1992, Trojan)
There have also been numerous 'best of' compilations released.
