{{Coord|55.8745|N|38.115|E|display=title}} [[Image:GCTC.jpg|thumb|right|The grounds of the Gagarin Cosmonauts Training Center]]
The '''Yuri A. Gagarin State Scientific Research-and-Testing Cosmonaut Training Center''' ('''GCTC'''; [[Russian language|Russian]]: Центр подготовки космонавтов имени Ю. А. Гагарина)<ref>{{lang-ru|Российский Государственный Научно-Исследовательский Испытательный Центр Подготовки Космонавтов (РГНИИЦПК) им. Ю. А. Гагарина}}, {{lang|ru-Latn|Rossiyskiy Gosudarstvenny Nauchno-Issledovatelsky Ispytatelny Tsentr Podgotovki Kosmonavtov (RGNIITsPK) im. Yu. A. Gagarina}}</ref> is a [[Russia]]n training facility responsible for training [[cosmonaut]]s for [[List of Russian manned space missions|their space missions]]. It is in [[Star City, Russia|Star City]] of [[Moscow Oblast]], a name which may refer to the facility itself or to its grounds.
==Formation== The facility was originally known only as Military Unit 26266 or в/ч 26266, and was a secret training base for Soviet Cosmonaut candidates. The site was chosen for its proximity to Moscow and other infrastructure that would be essential for its function: Chkalovsky Airbase, and the Yaroslavl railroad.<ref name=BHp30>Burgess and Hall, p.30</ref> The densely forested area was originally a radar range with some existing infrastructure.<ref>[http://www.gctc.ru/main.php?id=242 Центр подготовки космонавтов]</ref>
Military physician Colonel Yevgeny Karpov was appointed as the first chief of the cosmonaut training centre or ''Tsentr Podgotovki Kosmonavtov'' (TsPK) on February 24, 1960.<ref>Burgess and Hall, p.29</ref> The centre was home to approximately 250 personnel divided into various departments who were responsible for the development of all aspects of the space program ranging from equipment to the well being of the cosmonauts. These included specialists in heat exchange and hygiene, survival clothing, surgery, and training staff. Initially cosmonaut candidates were housed at the nearby Frunze Central Airfield (Moscow), followed by an apartment block in Chkalovsky<ref name=BHp30/> before eventually moving to the newly built apartments on site where they would remain with their families throughout training<ref>[http://tass.ru/kosmos/4641336 Новым начальником Центра подготовки космонавтов стал Максим Харламов // ТАСС]</ref>.
==Civilian administration== Until April 2009 the center was owned and operated by the [[Russian Ministry of Defense]] in cooperation with [[Roskosmos|Russian Federal Space Agency]]. On April 2009, Russia President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] signed a [[ukaz|presidential decree]] transferring the center from the Defence Ministry to the [[Russian Federal Space Agency]] (Roskosmos)<ref>Itar Tass, ''Medvedev demands hand over Cosmonauts Training Center to Roskosmos'', 10.4.09</ref>
The Cosmonaut Training Center was inaugurated on January 11, 1960 in [[Star City, Russia|Star City]] outside [[Moscow]].{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} In 1969 it was named after [[Yuri Gagarin]], the first man to fly in [[Outer space|space]]. In 1995 the Cosmonaut Training Center and Air Force Test and Training regiment were merged and reorganized into its current form.{{Clarify|date=December 2010}}
==Key infrastructure== The facility contains infrastructure essential for the training of cosmonauts across a wide range of experiences, including simulating g-loads, mission specific/suit training, medical observation/testing and astronavigation.
Key GCTC facilities include: *Full-size [[mockup]]s of all major spacecraft developed since the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, including the [[Soyuz spacecraft|Soyuz]] and [[Shuttle Buran|Buran]] vehicles, the [[TKS spacecraft|TKS modules]] and orbital stations of the [[Salyut Program]], [[Mir]], and [[International Space Station|ISS]]. These were co-existing or with time replaced one another inside two main training hangar halls of the Center. Room 1 houses the Salyut 4, 6, Mir (Don-17KS) with Kvant (Don-37KE), Kvant 2 (Don-77KSD) and Kristall (Don-77KST) modules and a Soyuz 2 descent module simulators. Room 1A houses the Soyuz simulators (Don-7ST3 -old STK-7ST - for the Soyuz TMA; TDK-7ST4 - old TDK-7TS2 for Soyouz TM - for the Soyuz TMM; Don-732M modified for Soyuz TM and the Pilot 732 - for the TORU docking system).Other rooms house the [[Salyut 7]], [[Spektr]] (Don-77KSO), [[Priroda]] (Don-77KSI), Buran, [[Zarya]] and [[Zvezda (ISS module)|Zvezda]] simulators. *Zero-gravity training aircraft for simulating weightlessness (cf. [[Vomit Comet]]), including the [[MiG-15]] UTI, [[Tupolev Tu-104]] and later the [[IL-76]] MDK with internal volume of {{convert|400|m3|cuft}}. Training aircraft are based at the Russian Air Force base at [[Airport Chkalovskiy|Chkalovskiy airfield]].{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} *A Medical observation clinic and testing facility. *The original office of [[Yuri Gagarin]] and a number of monuments and busts to him and other cosmonauts.
